theText: I wishOn behalf of the members for Riverina, Mackellar and Fraser, I express our special thanks to our High Commissioner in the Solomon Islands, Mr Patrick Cole, and his staff, and the leaders and staff of RAMSI and the aid agencies. I thank the government and the people of the Solomon Islands for their hospitality. I also give a very big thank you to Neil Bessell, the delegation secretary, for assistance above and beyond the call of duty. AndI should not forget to thank the boat driver, who brought us all safely through the storm-there was no preselection needed in any of those electorates! Question agreed to. theText: Monday, 20 June 2005 ----Franklin Electorate: Community Work Training pilot training program in my electorate of Franklin. I am referring to the certificate II course in community work recently completed in Clarendon Vale and Bridgewater-Gagebrook. Access to training is a huge barrier to overcome for people in disadvantaged suburbs. Neighbourhood houses and family support in my electorate provide a facility for women, single-parent and two-parent families-amongst others-to gather and learn in an informal environment. These people, who traditional schooling failed, now wish to re-enter the work force and need to access formal training and education. They need skill development and, more importantly, workplace opportunities. APW Training, which is part of the Anglicare organisation, obtained funding from the VET priority placements program-or PPP-to run a program for people returning to the work force, people with disabilities and mature age people on a benefit. Training took place in the local environment-in this case neighbourhood houses in Gagebrook and Clarendon Vale. This was a brave move and a welcome initiative from APW. Enrolments exceeded expectations-there were 12 at Clarendon Vale and 14 at Gagebrook. Participants on the course had to overcome many problems, but lateral thinking and committed resources produced solutions that enabled all participants to continue. At graduation ceremonies last week, graduates told of their pride, increased confidence and higher self-esteem not to mention the camaraderie with fellow students that will develop into long-lasting friendships. Out of 26 enrolments, 24 students graduated last week. TAFE and other education and training providers would kill for that kind of retention rate. Medical reasons accounted for the two who did not finish. Hard on the heels of this success, celebrations are a touch guarded because, in spite of the employers’ rave reviews of students during their work placements, certificate II graduates need to go on and complete certificate III to be employed in the field. There are employers waiting for this group to attain their level III certification. Funding is desperately needed to enable the next step of this training program to commence. In the interests of the participants, potential employers and the community, the certificate III course should start as soon as possible. VET PPP funding is now somewhere between the Australian government and the states. Talks continue between federal and state bodies, but unfortunately government departments move slowly. I have had discussions with the relevant ministers in this place to find the money to ensure this pilot program delivers the certificate III in community work to these 24 participants. The vibes are positive. Censorship watch in the privacy of their homes is largely up to them. title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Neville (Hinkler) (5.02 Pm)
theText: Let me say that I am no prude. What adults want toment has no artistic merit whatsoever and no justification for the gratuitous sex that it offers. We have a reasonably good censorship regime in this country. We have general exhibition, parental guidance, two levels of M certification-one requiring the accompaniment of adults-and the R classification category. Everyone knows what they are watching. We understand that X classification films are not generally available for exhibition in cinemas. They are made and distributed in the ACT and the Northern Territory. The government did not approve the move towards non-violent erotica, which would have mollified Australians into believing that they were watching something a bit naughty but not too harmful. If this is the standard we set for the exhibition of films in cinemas, where people choose to pay their money, or for their sale as videos then are we not entitled to expect that free-to-air television maintains the same if not a higher standard? Why? Because by their very definition free-to-air films are available to all Australians and hold a privileged place in Australian households. We are therefore entitled to believe that classification is more important in this context. People do not deserve to be affronted by material that would otherwise be excluded under normal censorship provisions. For that reason, I understand the anger of people who have been affronted by Big Brother and Big Brother Uncut. Surely we have not stooped to such a level in Australia in free-to-air television that community debate centres around whether Michelle and Glenn had real sex or not. Quite apart from the mind-numbing banality of most of this reality television, do we really need to further degrade the standards of Australian television production and presentation to such a pathetic level? The program, to which so many people have objected, cannot be justified on the grounds of artistic merit. Let us hope it is not a genuine reflection of Australian society, the other classic justification. Let us be frank: some episodes are nothing more than gratuitous sex and innuendo, and I seriously question whether our censorship authorities, particularly Channel 10 internally and the ABA, are doing their job. (Time expired) Whaling to the slaughter of whales in Australian waters. I want to illustrate the overwhelming and passionate reaction that my community and indeed all Australians have had to Japanese whaling. On behalf of our community, I urge the Prime Minister to stop the rhetoric and start acting on this issue. On SundayI had the privilege of attending a special community-driven protest against whaling in Australian waters. ThereI received many heartfelt drawings and letters, mostly from local children, asking the Prime Minister to put a stop to Japan’s whaling plans. I ask the Prime Minister to please listen to what these children are saying. Rebecca says: These are precious creatures. I think they deserve to live. That’s why I’m totally against the idea of hunting whales. Perry writes: You are the only Australian that has the power to try and end it. Please put pressure on the Japanese to stop whaling MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mrs Elliot (Richmond) (5.05 Pm)
theText: TodayI want to raise my community’s objectionsRuby says: I wait every year for the whales to come and if you take this away from me and everyone else that enjoys this, we will be very upset. Mason says: You really should stop the whaling. It will badly hurt the tourism in my town. Jesse says: I think you have the powers to make a difference. Whales have rights too. Grace says: We want you to put pressure on them to stop this madness. Maraya says: There is one humpback whale that comes up and down the east coast, which is where I live, and I would some day like to see it. However, I won’t be able to do that if it’s dead. Robert says: We think that you could stop all of this. The whales are precious. They’re beautiful. Charam says: I’d really like you to at least try and do something. I know you have a lot to do but if you think about it, whales should be at the top of your priority list. Hannah says: I am very disturbed by the Japanese killing the very beautiful whales because if they do they’ll be no whales left for our children’s children to see and admire. Grace says: Whales are beautiful animals and don’t deserve to be harmed. Imagine if someone started hunting you down for your fat. I hope that the Prime Minister takes these messages from local children straight to the Japanese government. The drawings are heartfelt and illustrate how passionate the children are about this very, very important issue, and I will be sending all of these-about 50 drawings in total-to the Prime Minister so that he can see them and read the children’s letters and hear how desperately passionate they are about this very important issue. Whaling in Australian waters is indeed unacceptable-it is as simple as that, and the government should be taking greater action in relation to it. I note also that the member for Moncrieff has sent a petition to the Gold Coast council calling upon them to take action in relation to their sister city in Japan and the issue of whaling. I would like to say to the member for Moncrieff that he should be speaking to his fellow coalition MPs and the Prime Minister about taking action, not sending a petition to the Gold Coast council. He should be speaking to the Prime Minister and getting him to take some action. My community feels very strongly about this; there were at least 100 people at the community gathering on Sunday, mostly children, who presented these drawings and who feel strongly about this. I will be forwarding them to the Prime Minister and urging him to take action on this very important issue. We have to protect the whales and we have to do it now. MAIN COMMITTEE Ryan Electorate our social fabric and I want to pay tribute to them in the parliament today. It is estimated that if a cash value were put on the hours that volunteers spend in this country it would amount to some $50 billion. That is why I think it is important that all members of the federal parliament pay tribute to the volunteers in their respective electorates. I want to commend the federal government very strongly today because it has allocated some $11,400 to the Ryan electorate, which I of course have the great privilege of representing here in the parliament. It has permitted 10 local community organisations to benefit from this, and I want to pay tribute to and acknowledge them here in the parliament today. The Gap Pioneer and History Group, under the stewardship of Mr Jeff Hilder, has received almost $2,000; his organisation will benefit tremendously from this. The Kenmore branch of Little Athletics, under the guidance of Mrs Diane Thornton, is going to receive some $1,600, which will go towards a marquee. The Moggill Cricket Association, under the guidance of Mr Ian Bartholomew, is going to receive some $2,281, which will go towards putting up a quickshade. Also, very importantly, the Moggill branch of the Queensland Country Women’s Association, under the guidance of Mrs Robyn Brand, will receive $1,400-plus towards a roving microphone, a microwave, a benchtop food warmer and some portable tables. The branch does a wonderful job in the Ryan electorate. The Centenary Meals on Wheels, under the guidance of Miss Sandra Goode, who lives in Jindalee, will receive over $600 towards mobile phone handsets and some eskies. These are examples of the wonderful organisations throughout the country, and it is very important that we pay tribute to them. The Queensland branch of the Scout Association of Australia, under the guidance of Mr Ken Whyte, who lives at Mount Ommaney, will receive over $600 towards a colour printer. This is an example of how good local membership can help local community organisations. Accordingly, $11,000 has been provided to the Ryan electorate and 10 organisations will benefit. These funds will make an important contribution to the viability of these organisations, for which people give up their time to contribute to the local community. I want to mention one more: the Moggill Scout Group, under the guidance of Mr Norm Holliman, who lives in Bellbowrie, will receive almost $900 to go towards coolers and an outboard motor, which will make an important difference to the activities of the young people in the Moggill community. title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Neville
theText: We are great supporters of the sugar industry.
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Murphy
theText: I know you are. The Brazilian government first mandated a five per centleading sugar cane and ethanol producer in the world. By adding ethanol to gasoline, Brazil has secured its energy needs and created many job opportunities as well as a reduction in pollution and the lowering of greenhouse gas emissions. It is well known that sugar cane producers in Australia are struggling. My concern is that the government continues to subsidise an inefficient industry without helping it to go in different directions-for example, by providing further financial assistance to the sugar cane producers to encourage them to make ethanol. It is also well known that the oil industry is a very powerful lobby. It is disgraceful that many petrol stations in Sydney put out messages guaranteeing that no ethanol is mixed in the gasoline. This perpetuates the myth to Sydney motorists that ethanol is harmful to the motors of ordinary cars. Nothing could be further from the truth. A mix of 10 per cent ethanol with gasoline is a very safe and environmentally friendly measure. In Brazil today, all cars run on a minimum of 25 per cent ethanol. Brazil has shown the world that the use of ethanol to power motor vehicles is the way to go, both environmentally and economically. I can report first hand that the Brazilians are laughing at the almost daily price hikes in the cost of a barrel of oil. Oil is a finite resource and it is not environmentally friendly, so today I call on the Howard government to follow Brazil’s example and to do everything to assist and encourage the production of ethanol in Australia. I am sure that one day, once Australians discover for themselves that the mix of 10 per cent ethanol with gasoline is not dangerous to their motor vehicles, Australia, like Brazil, will produce cars that run on 25 per cent to 100 per cent ethanol. That would be good for our environment and for the economy. Unexploded Ordnance exploded ordnance in Australia. For those who might not be aware of what this is, unexploded ordnance includes bombs, artillery shells and similar munitions that lie idle and unexploded, a potential hazard, in hundreds of locations right around our nation. There are currently 1,196 identified UXO sites around Australia, and one of those sites is in my electorate of Fisher on the Sunshine Coast. I have been fighting to make sure that we achieve an appropriate outcome and an equitable solution with respect to the issue of UXOs. On the Sunshine CoastI believe that all levels of government bear some responsibility for the current situation. Obviously the Australian government was defending Australia and these particular items were fired as part of our defence preparations. However, the principal problem locally has been caused by the fact that the government of Queensland permitted the freeholding of the land and its use for sub-divisional purposes and the City of Caloundra approved sub-divisional plans without requiring in each case that the land be cleared of UXOs. So we have a situation where UXOs are partly on private property and also on public land. What we want is an outcome that will ensure that they are cleared from those areas where they pose a danger to the public. As a parent, I, of course, experience concerns when I look at the dangers to young children when they locate these UXOs. Happily, no lives have been lost, and let us hope that that remains the situation. The issue of UXOs locally was recently ignited when a team from the Caloundra City Council, using a mini excavator, came across what they suspected was a UXO. They were doing water mains work on a road owned by the Queensland state government. Naturally, the MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Slipper (Fisher) (5.14 Pm)
theText: There has been an ongoing debate over the issue of unwork was brought to a standstill as their Caloundra Council superiors were notified and they in turn notified the police and the military authorities. As it turned out what they had found was not a UXO at all; it was something else. However, the local state member, Chris Cummins, jumped on the bandwagon and claimed that the Australian government should bear the full cost of clearing these items. The Caloundra City Council and I have had discussions and they are coming forward with a plan of what they suggest should be done, but, as I said earlier, all levels of government bear some responsibility here-particularly the state government and the local authority, because we would not have the present situation had the state government not approved the freeholding and had Caloundra City Council not permitted the plans for the subdivision to proceed. What we need to do is look at those areas of public land that are used by the public, work out a map and work out costings. In my view, there then has to be an appropriate compromise arrangement whereby the federal government, the state government and the local council work together to remove this potential menace. (Time expired) Northern Territory Election noon and congratulate Clare Martin and the Labor team in the Northern Territory on their historic win last Saturday. Ms Hall-An outstanding result. it, especially as some of my conservative colleagues are here in the chamber. What we have seen is an absolute routing of the CLP-the Country Liberal Party-in the Northern Territory. It has been such a routing that we have seen a swing to Clare Martin and her governmentthe Labor Party-of 20.3 percent. A swing like that to a government is unprecedented. As a result, we have seen the leader of the opposition, Denis Burke, have a swing of 22 per cent against him and he has lost his seat. I might point out that in the last election Matthew Bonson, an Aboriginal bloke, stood for the seat of Millner. He won that seat with a margin of 80 votes. I am happy to announce that he won this time with a 22 per cent swing and now sits on 73.2 per cent, a margin all of us in this place would like to have. I would also point out that two other Indigenous candidates were elected to the Territory’s assembly-as new members. Alison Anderson, a former ATSIC commissioner, won the seat of MacDonnell, with a swing of-wait for it-30.5 per cent. Barbara McCarthy won the seat of Arnhem with a slightly lower swing-only 15.2 per centbecause she was taking it over from a former Labor member. She got a massive swing on the top of taking over the seat from Jack Ah Kit, a previous Labor minister. Labor also won the seat of Daly from the CLP. In that seat Bob Knight got a reasonable swing-30.4 per cent. He now sits on a margin of 70.8 percent. These are historically unprecedented results. Another candidate, and the person who has beaten the Territory Leader of the Opposition, is James Burke. As it happens, his father stood for the Labor Party in the 1983 election when the Labor Party only won six seats-something like the CLP is going to win this time. His father stood for the seat of Wanguri but lost. James Burke now has the pleasure of saying, although his father stood for the Labor Party in 1983, that he stood this year-in 2005-and he defeated the Leader of the Opposition. That is not a bad result. MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Snowdon (Lingiari) (5.17 Pm)
theText: It is my great pleasure at to stand here this after
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Snowdon
theText: It was an outstanding result and it gives me great pleasure to talk aboutQantas Services Townsville. They came in flying boats. They were running flights from Sydney’s Rose Bay through to Brisbane which then stopped at Gladstone in the member for Hinkler’s electorate before landing in Townsville en route to Singapore and London. These days we have something a little more significant than a flying boat service from Qantas. I am pleased to advise the parliament that on Friday, Jetstar, which is part of the Qantas group, announced that it will be servicing Townsville with some very significant new services. I am very pleased to see that Jetstar will run a service which I believe is a first-that is, Melbourne-Townsville direct. That is a great result, particularly for our commercial and our military people in Townsville because many of them have families and friends in the southern part of the state. We will now see Qantas running 38 services a week to Townsville. Jetstar will run 14 services a week to Townsville and QantasLink, the other member of the Qantas stable, will run 49 services to Townsville. This gives a total of 101 services every week from the Qantas group. I really appreciate the support that Qantas has shown to our city, Australia’s largest tropical city. I know that it will continue to operate and to offer appropriate services for our region. Townsville also has Virgin services. Another airline, which is known as Alliance Airlines, provides jet services from Townsville. So we are well serviced as the regional communications and business centre of the north. I also note that Qantas has a national partnership with Tourism Australia in relation to a major marketing thrust over the next three years to promote Australia and to promote inbound tourism. Qantas has once again demonstrated through this partnership that it does call Australia home. It is committed to working with Tourism Australia globally and it is committed to growing Australia’s tourism industry from all major regions. That is why I would like to strongly support Qantas in its position as flagship carrier for Australia and to support anything that we can do as a government that will help it. (Time expired) Education the Annunciation Primary School, Pagewood, and St Aidan’s Primary School, Maroubra. These petitions call on the federal government to respect the wishes of their teachers to maintain current awards registered by consent with the New South Wales Industrial Relations Commission between non-government school employers and the Independent Education Union. They very reasonably ask that basic rights at work guaranteed under New South Wales industrial relations are also enshrined in federal industrial legislation. I will table these petitions in the House of Representatives during this sitting week. As the member for Kingsford SmithI support the teachers at these schools and their call for the maintenance of their current hard-won rights. These petitions are more evidence of the degree of concern the community of Kingsford Smith has about the Howard government’s approach to and performance in education-from primary schools to universities and on a number of fronts. The Senate committee’s student income support report will be tabled shortly. Alarmingly, its findings reveal that over one-third of students are living below the poverty line. The report finds that, on average, students must work at least 20 hours per week simply to survive. This means that they are either skipping lectures and only attending tutorials or attending tutorials and getting their lecture notes MAIN COMMITTEE

title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Garrett (Kingsford Smith) (5.23 Pm)
theText: I have received petitions from Our Lady offrom the internet. This practice, I can verify from students at the University of New South Wales, is increasing. Students therefore are not able to achieve their best results and they end up simply doing the bare minimum to scrape by. I think members would agree that that is a completely unacceptable situation for our future teachers, future doctors, future health technicians, future lawyers, future surveyors and so on to find themselves in. Their capacity to act as competent professionals once they graduate is very much determined by their ability to focus properly on their studies during the term of their education, and if most of them-or many of them-find themselves on the poverty line, this capacity is greatly impaired. The ongoing and, it must be said, destructive pattern of reduced funding in higher education means for instance that students of few means have less access to scholarships as universities such as University of New South Wales struggle to provide services previously supplied through federal government funding. Already facing strained and difficult circumstances, these students are now faced with a mounting attack on student unions-the so-called voluntary student unionism attack. It is against the wishes of the majority of students and universities. We should oppose government policy that jeopardises the capacity of students to study, as they scrabble to make ends meet-even to the extent of offering themselves for medical experiments, as we read in the newspapers last week. At the same time these students now face removal of services that are so significant to them: counselling, legal advice, sports facilities and the like. The education of Australian students deserves better. Workplace Relations Reform of these new industrial relations reforms. My brother and I ran three restaurants and, combining full-time, part-time permanent and casual employees, we had around 60 employees on our books at any given time. The scare campaign by the unions would have you believe that employers will now be able to fire people just for the sake of it. This notion is ridiculous to anyone who has owned or has been associated with small business. The old mentality of labour just being one component in the manufacturing process along with other raw materials and other inputs is thinking of an age gone by. I can tell you, as other small business people can, that your staff-or team, as the current mentality would have it-are the most important component in any business and that you must treat them very well. These people are essential to the smooth running of the organisation and to exploit them or to terminate them only hurts you and your business. In most organisations the owner of the business and his or her team form great friendships, long-lasting even well after the business is sold or the employee leaves. I still keep in contact with many former employees and I am willing to assist-as I have-with references or advice. However, I have also been the victim of employees who have had personal problems, where the stealing of money, goods and time have occurred; where they have openly defied responsibility by hiding behind unfair dismissal laws and the so-called ‘three written warnings’ before termination can occur otherwise industrial action will occur-that is, through the courts. I know many other employers who would take on extra staff if the unfair dismissal laws were removed today. The law must protect employees, I agree. However, the survival of small business is precarious at best and I see the future industrial relations laws as a muchneeded shot in the arm for the backbone of this country. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Statements By Members

speaker: Mr Vasta (Bonner) (5.26 Pm)
theText: As a former business owner I know first-hand the valueHall Electorate: Specialists Ms HALL (Shortland) (5.28 pm)-An issue was raised with me in my electorate last week that I think is worth bringing before the House. It relates to continuing referrals to specialists. It is possible for our constituents to obtain a continuing referral from their general practitioner that enables them to see a specialist without being required to go back and get a new referral. Unfortunately, this is not widely known and therefore very few specialists accept this. Only if our constituents ask their general practitioner can they get a continuing referral, but even when they have one sometimes specialists are quite reticent in taking up the referrals. I would like this parliament to put in place proper procedures whereby specialists are made aware of the importance of these referrals and of the fact that they are acceptable, and to undertake an information campaign to advise general practitioners that continuing referrals are available so patients can benefit from them. agreed to on 14 July 2005, the time for members’ statements has concluded. The apparent success of Japan in bringing this issue to the point where they are actually arguing to hunt humpback whales and other species and to expand their quota of whales slaughtered for so-called scientific purposes raises a number of issues. One issue, which is agreed by everyone in this parliament, is that whaling is an activity which should be consigned to the dustbin of history; that it is inappropriate to hunt and slaughter whales in the cruel way in which it is currently being done by a small number of countries. title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (5.31 Pm)
theText: This is a critical week for Migaloo, the whitefront. But I must say that there is considerable concern that inaction has brought us to this point. It appears, from Senate estimates last month, that the foreign minister did not make any representations to Japan on this issue between 1996 and 2004. We have also seen the environment minister undertake a last-ditch attempt to travel around the world in the couple of weeks leading up to the IWC. This suggests that the government has been asleep at the wheel while Japan has been busy recruiting countries who would vote for its pro-whaling position. It is also the case, I believe, that mixed messages have been sent. In particular, I refer to the Humane Society International case, in which the Attorney-General, Philip Ruddock, intervened and made a submission stating that the case should not be allowed because it would ‘lead to an international disagreement with Japan’. We do have an international disagreement with Japan when it comes to the issue of whaling. The legal intervention on whaling stands in very stark contrast to the action in 1999 where the government took Japan-the same country-to the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea over southern bluefin tuna and was, in fact, represented in that case by the then Attorney-General, Daryl Williams. It seems to the Labor Party that it is entirely appropriate that diplomatic measures not only take place but be backed up by legal measures. In particular, the government should take action in the International Court of Justice to stop whaling. At the IWC meeting held in Adelaide there was a legal opinion given to suggest that the actions of Japan and other whaling nations were a clear breach of the provisions in the IWC which outlawed whaling and that so called scientific whaling was clearly not occurring and was an abuse. Given that the government made much of the changes to the EPBC Act 1999, which the Prime Minister was prepared to quote in the 2001 election policy of the coalition, saying that the slaughter of whales and dolphins in Australia’s territory should be stopped, why hasn’t the government been prepared to take legal action to stop the illegal slaughter of whales in Australian waters? (Time expired) Heritage) (5.36 pm)-In response to our amiable friend from the opposition, the member for Grayndler, I have three points about the government’s position on whaling. First, the government’s position on whaling is absolutely clear: we stand utterly opposed to whaling in any form. Our friend from the other side raises the point that in 1999 the Australian government, through the form of the then Attorney-General, were willing to take the Japanese to court in relation to the bluefin case. What that demonstrates is that there is no fear of taking action. What we do is take steps as and when appropriate and necessary. I would note particularly the words of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who has very specifically-and I quote the words precisely-said: We have not ruled out any legal or diplomatic options to bring further pressure to Japan if that is necessary, but we obviously have to work these things through carefully, step by step ... So the position and the possibility there is clear and open, but the first task is to fight within the context of the International Whaling Commission. The Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Campbell, has spared absolutely no effort in that process. His life, the government’s efforts and the full efforts of our diplomatic service over a long period have been dedicated to precisely the care and protection of whales. So that is the first point. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Hunt (Flinders
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment andThe second point is: what is the government’s formal position on scientific and commercial whaling? We are dead against both. We are absolutely, fundamentally, categorically against scientific whaling and commercial whaling. My definition of ‘scientific whaling’ is a photograph, a tracking device and a hug to send them on their way. That is about as far as it gets from our perspective. But we stand completely, resolutely, absolutely against them. The third thing is: what about the International Whaling Commission? We have heard from the member for Grayndler that it will be a catastrophe. I am delighted to report to the House a small, early, preliminary victory which has become known only in the last couple of hours. I hope the member for Grayndler hears this. I quote from a newswire report just received: Japan failed today to passand I hope that the member for Grayndler pays attentionan early procedural vote at the International Whaling Commission, suggesting the body would remain dominated by the anti-whaling lobby, as it has been for 23 years. So that is an initial step. The points in relation to our friend from the opposition are very simple. Firstly, we have been strong in relation to the protection of our waters, and we will continue to be so. Secondly, we utterly reject scientific and commercial whaling as unacceptable practices in the 21st century. Thirdly, we have had a very clear result just in the last couple of hours which is promising, which is preliminary. There is a lot more to do. We are against strong forces. But we will be absolutely clear in fighting to prevent whaling. Ms GEORGE (Throsby) (5.40 pm)-I would like to raise a matter with the parliamentary secretary. He was a member of a House of Representatives committee which produced a report on employment in the environment sector which was tabled in November 2003. To date, neither the department nor the government appear to have responded to many of the very important recommendations in that report. They are asleep at the wheel on a number of issues to do with the environment, this being another one of them. In particular tonight I want to raise the fact that in Australia we lack a comprehensive national data collection on the scope of the environment industry in this country. We might have differences about and debate what exactly we mean by the environment industry, but state by state there has been progress made in trying to identify the scope of green jobs and the environment industry. However nothing has happened at the national level. This is a great tragedy because back in 2001 one of the recommendations made in the Environment Industry Action Agenda was that the ABS, together with the department, ought to get a move on and ensure that comprehensive information was available. From what I understand, the Australian Bureau of Statistics were quite open to the proposal because they had had a number of requests from industry members, from overseas and from international bodies in other countries asking for comparable data on the scope of the environment industry in Australia. In 2001 the ABS actually released a paper, the ABS Prospectus on a national survey of the environment industry. The ABS indicated that they were quite capable of carrying out such analysis and that they believed the cost of doing so would be in the order of $1.54 million for the initial survey. They estimated it would take about $1 million annually to keep that data up to date. They indicated then that they were not in a position to finance the work. MAIN COMMITTEE The matter has been raised on numerous occasions and was again raised in the report from the committee of which the parliamentary secretary was a member. Interestingly enough, the first significant recommendation was as follows: The Committee recommends that the Australian Government provide the additional funding required to enable the Australian Bureau of Statistics to collect and make available ongoing and trend data on the environment industry in Australia. The committee went on to say: ... failure to do so may impede the development of the industry and hence result in greater long term national costs to Australia. SoI am quite amazed that, year after year, attention is drawn to the obvious inadequacies in terms of having a national response to issues to do with green jobs, employment opportunities, the scope of the domestic market, the rate at which that market is growing and the export potential for green technologies. Despite many references to the need to have such data on a national basis, here we are today with no comprehensive figures that can be verified by the ABS. It appears from the budget papers-I certainly cannot find a line item on this-that the government is not responding in a serious way to this glaring omission. Heritage) (5.44 pm)-I wish to make two points in response to the member for Throsby’s contribution. The first is in relation to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Heritage report on employment in the environment sector. It was a pleasure and a honour to share membership of that committee with the member for Throsby. In relation to that specific report, we are very close to a final presentation. One of the reasons for that delay is precisely because of the fact that we have taken this seriously. We have looked at all of the points. It is very close to a final position. I do take a personal responsibility for seeing something like that through. I have had a role in both helping to prepare the report and helping to respond to it. They are personal responsibilities and I accept the need to undertake them. We are actually in a very good position. My second comment is in relation to jobs and the environment. I note simply that the Australian government recently established the Australian water fund, which is about $2 billion for one sector of the environment. That will have a profound effect both on employment, on efficiency and on environmental care and protection. palling performance of the government when it comes to protecting Australia’s heritage. We have seen only nine sites listed on the National Heritage List. The government’s failure in this area is perhaps best exemplified by the fact that they had a special provision in the legislation to list world heritage sites and yet they chose not to simply because they were, once again, complacent. Twelve months after becoming the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Minister Campbell still has not met with his key advisory body: the National Cultural Heritage Forum. What an extraordinary performance! This body has not met-not once. It is not surprising that the minister does not want to face his critics, because this is what forum members have been saying. Emeritus Professor John Mulvaney, Australia’s pre-eminent expert on Australia’s prehistory, said in the Canberra Times on 15 June: The public should realise the cavalier and biased manner in which the new Heritage Act is administered. title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (5.44 Pm)
theText: I wish to raise the issue of heritage and the apProfessor Simon Molesworth, the Chairman of the Australian Council of National Trusts, on 12 March said: The credibility of the Government’s heritage system is in question thanks to this grinding haltthat is, the grinding halt in protecting places. Professor Bill Logan, former chairman of the National Cultural Heritage Forum, said: In a single act, the federal Environment and Heritage Ministerthat is, Minister Campbellthreatens to bring the entire national heritage list into disrepute. The Australasian Institute for Maritime Archaeology speaking about the Howard government’s roadworks at ANZAC Cove, which perhaps best exemplify the government’s contempt for looking after our heritage, said: ... AIMA was alarmed by the recent damage to this near-pristine archaeological site. The current works program has done more than compromise the archaeological integrity of fragile relics situated along the length of the affected road area ... may have impacted on archaeological remains within the near-shore areas. They continued: If the current management practices are allowed to continue more of Australia’s and Turkey’s cultural heritage will be lost. With regard to ANZAC Cove, we saw an absolute farcical situation whereby damage was done to one of World War I’s best-preserved battlefields. During last Friday’s Senate inquiry, it became clear that the Department of Environment and Heritage was not even made aware of the Howard government’s August 2004 request for roadworks. Perhaps what is even worse is that departmental officers were not aware of the damage caused until they read about it in the Daily Telegraph-this is according to their own evidence at that hearing. Heritage considerations were not borne in mind at all-which is extraordinary. I think it is up to the parliamentary secretary here, because he has been given the berth on this issue and Minister Truss has been exiled. It is extraordinary that the Minister for the Environment and Heritage was silent when it came to the issue of ANZAC Cove and the destruction that was caused at that site. Why has the Howard government failed so appallingly when it comes to heritage protection, when it comes to the listing of sites and when it comes to meetings of the National Cultural Heritage Forum? The only time that the minister has intervened and shown some leadership was the reactionary move to intervene against the Victorian government’s decision on alpine grazing. I would be interested in the parliamentary secretary’s view of that issue and how that reflected this government’s attitude towards our heritage. practice which had bipartisan support, at least for a number of years, in this parliament, and that was the giving of grants to conservation organisations at a national and state level and which by the action of the environment minister has now been reduced to virtually nil. I want to put on record my great appreciation of the work that voluntary conservation organisations at a state and national level have done in this country prior to the existence of the current act. In fact, I think that probably since the time of the Fraser government voluntary conservation organisations have been in receipt of modest amounts of funds which have enabled them to MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Garrett (Kingsford Smith) (5.49 Pm)
theText: I want to draw attention to the end of aeducate the community, to campaign in their local areas and to achieve some very significant environmental outcomes. What has happened today is that environment groups have had $250,000 cut from them from most state conservation councils, and they find themselves losing out. Unfortunately, this is a trend that has been under way during the term of the Howard government and it reflects one of the most insidious trends that arise when ministers are making grants of this kind and deciding whether or not they will be maintained-that is, those who speak out are penalised. If you speak out now in Australia on conservation issues and you have an advocacy role, you can surely expect to find that this Howard government will reduce your funding and, by reducing the funding, hope to silence the voices of those in ordinary communities who seek to campaign on environment issues. I really deplore this trend, and I think it is not at all to the credit of the minister that, in this case, he has chosen to take such an action. It really renders this grants program pretty insignificant. It is really just a political program now; it does not have any aspects of the bipartisan structure that it has had in the past. Alarmingly, the cuts came one day before the end of the financial year. I just ask people to contemplate for a moment what it is like to run a state conservation council, particularly in the more remote states of South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory. These state conservation councils work cooperatively at the local level with local councils-they work with people of all political persuasions-and they work very effectively with the community; they are made up significantly of volunteers. The amount of money that gets provided for them generally to pay a coordinator or someone of that sort keeps them going. As a result of the minister’s decision, their future prospects are significantly impaired and their capacity to continue to do that work and even to organise the volunteers so the volunteers can continue to make their contribution is greatly reduced. I think it is a very sad day when that happens. It is worthwhile, while I am speaking to the House, to affirm the campaign outcomes that conservation councils, local organisations and national conservation organisations have achieved. We can go back as far as the Great Barrier Reef outcome and identify most of Australia’s major national icons that have endured and taken protection from actions taken by the Commonwealth and state governments to ensure their protection because of the campaigning that these community groups were involved in. I do not think I need to labour the point, but our national income is in part provided for us by sharing these places of great natural beauty with visitors both from within Australia and from other parts of the world. The campaigns that existed from the Great Barrier Reef right through to Ningaloo Reef, for the most part, have been opposed by those interests that would see it within their realm to take some income from abusing or exploiting the natural conservation area in question. But it is the conservation councils and their wider membership from local and community groups cast around the states which provide the community interest in ensuring that someone stands up for these natural areas. It is a matter of great regret that under this environment minister these tremendous contributors to protection of the environment in Australia have had their funding so significantly reduced. I can only condemn the action of the minister in the House. Heritage) (5.54 pm)-In responding very briefly to the member for Kingsford Smith, I have three brief points to make. The first is that in relation to the grants to voluntary environment and heritage organisations, the number of groups that received grants this year has increased MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Hunt (Flinders
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment andby 62, up to 128. I significantly note that the two largest recipients are conservation councils. For, I believe, the first time, 28 groups are receiving multiyear funding. The two largest grants were for three years of $60,000 each for the South Australian Conservation Council and for Environment Victoria. So the first point is that it is an increase in the number of groups; it includes multiyear funding and, significantly-and I will come to this in a minute-small groups, in many cases, have received grants for the first time. The second point is this notion that it is about people being closed down. Environment Victoria, as I have mentioned, was the group which did best. Only today, the Executive Director of Environment Victoria put an extremely critical argument about the government in the Herald Sun. That is his right. Marcus Godinho is, in fact, somebody I know and respect but with whom on many issues I disagree. But today, with the benefit of three-year funding, it is quite interesting that he gave one of his strongest arguments ever against the Commonwealth government. I think that is precisely the opposite of what the member for Kingsford Smith put forward. The third point is that it is my understanding that 91 new small organisations who have never received GVEHOs before have been given such grants for practical purposes around Australia. Those are groups such as the Dolphin Research Institute and the Clean Ocean Foundation. The head of the Dolphin Research Institute said to me: ‘For us, this money is gold. This is worth twice the value of any other grant because of the way in which it can be applied.’ So it does have a practical impact. I respect the views presented but I respectfully disagree. raise all the issues I would like to raise. Certainly, I want to associate myself with the comments of the member for Kingsford Smith when it comes to the GVEHO program. It is symptomatic of a government that is prepared to silence civil society when the funds to voluntary environmental organisations that have served this nation so well are cut off. In particular, I do not want to miss the opportunity to raise the most important issue when it comes to the environment-that is, climate change. The parliamentary secretary would be aware that today my private member’s bill, the Avoiding Dangerous Climate Change (Kyoto Protocol Ratification) Bill 2005, had its second reading. Would the parliamentary secretary and the government agree to have a full debate and a vote on that bill in the parliament, now that it has had its second reading? It should be up to the parliament to vote on it. I noticed the parliamentary secretary did not participate in the debate today, because he knows the right thing to do is to join with other countries to be part of the international effort. The member for Stirling and, most extraordinarily, the member for Tangney spoke today in the second reading debate on my private member’s bill, and the parliament should be aware of their comments. The member for Tangney said essentially that climate change was not occurring. He said: Glaciologists working at this glacier utterly reject global warming as the causes of this glacier’s retreat. He joined with the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, who also said that climate change is not occurring. But the member for Tangney has gone one step further, because he is calling for nuclear energy. Today, he said: Total radioactivity levels on earth are slightly less after the nuclear power process. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (5.56 Pm)
theText: Because of time constraints I am not able toThat is an extraordinary proposition from the member for Tangney, but not quite as extraordinary as last week, when in a doorstop the member for Tangney dismissed the after-effects of Chernobyl as a minor issue and said that the impact of Chernobyl was no greater than the impact of Three Mile Island. Is it the government’s position that Chernobyl was a minor hiccup that should not be held against those who have concerns about nuclear energy? Where is the government going on this issue, given the Prime Minister and others have been openly calling for a debate on this issue and expressing support for nuclear energy? We want to hold the government accountable. If it is the case that the government wants nuclear energy, we want to know which member opposite will put up their hand and say, ‘I want a nuclear reactor in my electorate’whether it is the member for Tangney, the member for Flinders or other members. This is an important issue, because it is a distraction from the fact that the government is not prepared to take the issue of climate change seriously and take action. If you look at the massive increases in greenhouse gas emissions in every sector of the economy-except in land clearing, which, due to the decisions of the Beattie and Carr governments, is why Australia will meet its target of 108 per cent on 1990 levels-it is of great concern that current projections by the Australian Greenhouse Office show emissions of 123 per cent by the year 2020 on 1990 levels. The final question which I would like addressed by the parliamentary secretary is: in an era of climate change, where such change is a dominant political and environmental issue, why was it confirmed that the Australian Greenhouse Office was abolished in the budget, following the announcement in October last year, and why is it that the National Oceans Office has also been abolished and taken back into the department? Isn’t it the case that, by doing that to the Australian Greenhouse Office and the National Oceans Office, their independence and ability to put forward positions will be stifled by a government which, when you go back to its attitude towards community organisations, is very clearly determined to stifle any dissent? Heritage) (6.01 pm)-I am delighted to present the Environment and Heritage portfolio appropriation for 2005-06, and I thank all members who have spoken. I have endeavoured to respond to them, and I will address one or two of the questions they have raised. Overall, I wish to address three things during the course of this response: firstly, some of the major items which are part of the government’s package; secondly, some of the specific initiatives; and, thirdly, the question of water and also climate change. In looking at the major items, it is important to note that the whole-of-government allocation in the current budget for expenditure on Environment and Heritage functions for the coming year is $3.2 billion. In particular, $923.7 million is within the Environment and Heritage portfolio itself. The major items can be categorised as follows. Firstly, there is $337 million for the Australian water fund-a fund which, I think it would be agreed by members of both sides, is an outstanding step forward in dealing with Australia’s water issues and water challenges. That is made up of $253 million for Water Smart Australia and $30 million for national water standards, both of which are administered by the National Water Commission, and a further $54 million for the Australian government’s community water grants, which will be administered jointly by the Department of the Environment and Heritage and the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. I think that is a tremendous initiative. A second MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Hunt (Flinders
theText: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment andcore initiative in the coming year is the $310 million for the Natural Heritage Trust. This is administered, again, by the two departments. A third element is $168 million for the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality. Those three elements together-the Australian water fund, the Natural Heritage Trust and the National Action Plan for Salinity and Water Quality-are absolutely fundamental, along with the greenhouse work we are doing, in providing the pillars of major practical work for the environment. The second element that I want to talk about is the set of specific new initiatives which are highlighted within the appropriations bill. Firstly, there is $100 million over five years for the Commonwealth environment research facilities, the CERFs. This includes $40 million to create a marine and tropical research facility, and $60 million more generally for environmental research. These are very important steps forward. There is an amount of $46.3 million over four years for the Australia-Antarctic air link-again, a very important step forward and a particular initiative proposed and driven by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Ian Campbell. In terms of national and regional security, there is $40.5 million over four years for the Australian tsunami warning system for the Indian Ocean and Pacific Ocean coastlines. Something which I am very pleased to support is a contribution of $19.8 million additional funding-which, rounded up, makes about $30 million all up-over six years to replace 12 of the Bureau of Meteorology’s oldest field meteorological offices around Australia. I was recently able to see the capacity that exists within a new field office and the way in which that gives us better forecasting capability. There are other significant initiatives that we take forward. They include $10.5 million for the National Heritage Investment Initiative, which in part answers some of the criticisms made by the member for Grayndler in relation to heritage. The focus is on practical heritage application and protection. There is $11.4 million for the Photovoltaic Rebate Program, $9½ million for regional marine planning, another $5.2 million over four years for the National Pollutant Inventory and, very importantly, $2 million for used oil recycling. So there is a series of initiatives. I also note the National Water Initiative going forward, specifically the investment of $1.8 billion in greenhouse and climate change responses. That is a very significant process and represents the total package that the Australian government announced over a year ago in relation to energy, greenhouse emissions and climate change. It is all of those things taken together. For those reasons, I commend the appropriation to the House. I believe it represents an important investment in the Australian environment and heritage sector. diture for the Environment and Heritage portfolio be agreed to. Proposed expenditure agreed to. Ms GILLARD (Lalor) (6.07 pm)-It is no surprise that today started with newspapers with banner headlines about the Howard government trashing democracy, because this evening the Howard government is trashing the opportunity to question the Minister for Health and Ageing on matters in the budget. We were advised that the minister for health would perMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: The Deputy Speaker (Hon. Bk Bishop)
theText: The question is that the proposed expensonally attend this consideration in detail, only to find that he is now not in attendance. Clearly that decision has been taken because the Medicare safety net cover-up has to continue. The minister would have been aware that many of our questions to him would have been about his personal state of knowledge about the likelihood-or, should I say, lack of likelihood-of the Howard government keeping its ‘iron-clad, rock solid guarantee’ on the Medicare safety net on the day it was given. Of course, the Howard government has pulled the old trick of sending along a different minister who cannot possibly know about someone else’s state of knowledge. However, what I will do is indicate the key areas in the Medicare safety net that require answers. These relate to the budget measure titled ‘Medicare-increase in thresholds for the Medicare safety net’. That measure stripped some $499 million from the Medicare safety net. I am in a position to supply those questions in writing to the Minister for Ageing, who is at the table. I note that one of Minister Abbott’s key political advisers is present in the gallery, so it ought to be a simple matter for the minister at the table to turn to Minister Abbott’s key political adviser and get a guarantee that these questions, which are in writing, will be answered in writing before the parliament rises today-given that Minister Abbott indicated he was going to be here and at the last minute is not here. The questions that I am seeking answers to on this appropriation are as follows. The recent Senate estimates process revealed that the minister’s department was well equipped with information about the escalating cost of the Medicare safety net. The Health Insurance Commission was providing weekly and monthly reports on the Medicare safety net. This included weekly data reports to the department which provided information such as actual Medicare safety net benefits paid. These weekly reports came on top of existing daily reports on Medicare being delivered by the HIC to the department. This weekly information was revealing to the department variations between the estimates in the cost of the safety net compared with the actual cost of 72 per cent in August, 60 per cent in July and 43 per cent in June. Against that backdrop where we know for sure that the department of health was getting weekly data about the cost blow-outs in the Medicare safety net, the questions the minister for health needs to answer-and the minister at the table needs to give an undertaking that he will answer-are these. On what date was the minister first briefed about the blow-out in costs? On how many occasions was he briefed? What actions did he take following these briefings? Is the minister-that is, the Minister for Health and Ageing-aware that an officer in the department of finance was concerned enough about the blow-out to contact the finance minister’s office on more than one occasion? When was the minister first made aware that an officer in the department of finance was so concerned he contacted the finance minister’s office? Given that the finance minister was orally briefed on this issue, does the minister for health maintain that he was not briefed or contacted by the finance minister or his office about the matter? Specifically, did the minister or his staff discuss the blow-out with the Prime Minister, the minister for finance, the Treasurer or their staff? If so, when and what were the contents of these discussions? Is the minister aware of a graph detailing the safety net blow-out consistently referred to by his departmental secretary at Senate estimates? Is the minister aware that his departmental secretary refused to table the graph despite repeated requests to do so? Will the minister now table that graph? MAIN COMMITTEE It ought to be a simple matter for the Minister for Ageing, now at the table, to ascertain from Mr Barnes in the gallery that she is in a position to offer a ministerial undertaking that these questions will be answered in writing, given the minister’s nonattendance at this consideration in detail debate, before the House rises this evening? that it is perfectly proper for the Minister for Ageing to be in attendance in these discussions in detail. The minister may reply now if she wishes to or at a later point in the debate. Ms JULIE BISHOP (Curtin-Minister for Ageing) (6.12 pm)-At this point I do not require nor do I seek advice from the member for Lalor on how I should conduct myself in this debate. I will wait until she has concluded her submissions before responding. Ms GILLARD (Lalor) (6.12 pm)-I understand that the Minister for Ageing would be attending in her capacity to answer questions in the consideration in detail debate insofar as they relate to allocations for ageing in the budget. The problem here is, of course, that she is the only person who has attended who could deal with the consideration in detail on health, given the nonattendance of the Minister for Health and Ageing. I am also in a position to supply questions to the minister at the table-and would seek an undertaking in respect of these as well-relating to the electorate by electorate data about the Medicare safety net. As I think anybody who participated in the last federal election campaign would be aware, the Minister for Health and Ageing released during the campaign electorate by electorate breakdowns of expenditure on the safety net. That was done during the campaign-probably one of the greatest own goals in Australian politics, but I will not let that delay me. What we know from Senate estimates is that the minister is regularly briefed on electorate by electorate breakdowns on Medicare safety net expenditure and that electorate by electorate expenditure can be ascertained from the regular report provided by the Health Insurance Commission to the department. So if the minister is not releasing this information publicly, that is not a cost matter; that is simply a public accountability matter-that is, he has data of relevance to the Australian community and he chooses to cover it up. On that basis I would ask for an undertaking from the minister at the table that the Minister for Health and Ageing will answer the following questions in writing before the close of parliament today. Firstly, why won’t the minister release information about the safety net by electorate, as he did during the last election, which revealed that those with the highest incomes and capacity to spend more are getting the most benefit from the safety net? Is the minister-that is, the Minister for Health and Ageing-aware that this information can be ascertained from the regular report provided from the HIC to the department? Given that his own department admitted to briefing the minister regularly on this data, why won’t the minister release it? I will now take steps to supply these questions in writing to the Minister for Ageing and I will seek her undertaking on them before the close of this consideration in detail debate. sponds to your question. Whilst there are a number of issues on ageing that I feel are quite important-I will be watching very carefully MAIN COMMITTEE

title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: The Deputy Speaker (Hon. Bk Bishop)
theText: It is a matter for the minister how she reto see what happens over the next 12 months with the trials that are taking place-tonight I would like to raise issues relating to health. The first is the issue of the Belmont Medicare office. One of the first acts of the Howard government was to close the Belmont Medicare office. It was closed not because it was not processing a high number of claims but for some perverse reason that I have yet to have explained to me. It supported a very elderly population. Old people in the electorate who did not have cars had to travel about 20 kilometres, to either Charlestown or Lake Haven, to access a Medicare office. Belmont is in a central position for the people of Swansea, an area that maintains a very elderly population. The Shortland electorate is the 10th oldest electorate in Australia, as I am sure the Minister for Ageing is aware. This is quite a big issue. The previous member for Shortland and I have submitted in excess of 20,000 signatures to this House from people within the electorate who really need the Medicare office reopened. I ask the minister to consider that request. The Medicare office at Toukley is, once again, an area with an elderly population. I have submitted petitions to this House of around 1,000 signatures from people within that area. There is poor transport provided in that area-it is private as opposed to public transportand it takes people an hour to two hours to travel some eight kilometres to the nearest Medicare office. The member for Dobell is in the chamber. I am sure he would like to join with me on this next issue: the need to address the chronic doctor shortage that exists on the Central Coast. Mr Ticehurst interjectingto see a doctor. Was that an agreement, Member for Dobell? worked with a number of organisations, including the Hunter Urban Division of GPs and the local council. I have called before for the member for Dobell to work with me on this issue to no avail. I think it is an absolute disgrace when elderly people have to wait for up to two or three weeks to get an appointment with a doctor. There is an absolute crisis on the Central Coast. If something does not happen now, I think the government will be culpable because people will lose their lives simply because they cannot get an appointment with their doctor. Unfortunately, the doctor shortage is increasing and is now finding its way into the Lake Macquarie area of the Shortland electorate. Once again, the extremities of the electorate-the people in the far north of the Central Coast-are experiencing the greatest doctor shortage. Within Lake Macquarie, the people on the southern end are experiencing the greatest shortage. Unless something happens soon, there is going to be a real crisis in this area. The final point that I want to raise is that, at the New South Wales ALP conference the weekend before last, Bob Carr announced that there would be an after-hours GP service set up in Wyong Hospital. WhatI am asking for tonight is an undertakingMr Ticehurst interjectingMAIN COMMITTEE

theText: People living on the Central Coast have to wait an inordinate amount of time

theText: Absolutely.
