theText: What was it that the member for Dobell said?
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Ticehurst
theText: I thought they were closing down the beds and wards at Wyong Hospital.at Wyong Hospital. But, believe me, the people of Wyong shire, the people that live in that area, do. (Extension of time granted) WhatI am doing tonight is calling on the government to support that after-hours clinic at Wyong Hospital, to work with the state government to ensure that the people of the Central Coast get the absolute best service that they can. They need that after-hours service. I would like the minister to come back to me with answers to those four questions. Health and Ageing is not here this evening to address these issues, because some of the ones that I am bringing up are vitally important, particularly dental care. This is a huge issue within my electorate, particularly considering that 20 per cent of the population are aged over 65. Health matters, and particularly dental health matters, are ones that I hear about every single day. So many people are having to wait, sometimes over two years, to get their teeth fixed or to get their dentures repaired. I often hear terrible stories of people in pain who are unable to eat and of people whose ill-fitting dentures have fallen out. The situations that some people are in because of the fact that the federal funding was removed from this program in 1997 are just horrendous across the board. In fact it is a constitutional responsibility for the federal government to provide for dental health care. I had hoped to ask the minister directly why that federal funding is not being put into this very important area, because it is not just your teeth that are affected-dental care can affect your overall health as well. It can have impacts upon people in terms of strokes and heart disease, and also for people suffering from diabetes. This really is a major health concern across the nation but particularly in my electorate, as I say, because of the large number of elderly people. I would like to hear from the minister as to when he intends adhering to the federal government responsibility, as contained in the Constitution, to ensure that there is funding for dental health care. The other major health issue that I want to raise with him is the absolute desperate need for a Medicare office in the southern section of my electorate. Presently people can only travel to Tweed or Lismore to access a Medicare office, and it is often very difficult-again, particularly for elderly people or for those on low incomes-for them to get transport to those areas. During the election campaign when Labor announced the policy of having a Medicare office in Mullumbimby, this was received so well by so many people who so desperately needed to have a Medicare office close by. I was hoping to ask the minister first-hand as to when there would be a Medicare office in the southern section of the Richmond electorate. The other matter that I want to raise is specifically in relation to ageing and the provision of home care. As I said, 20 per cent of the Richmond electorate are aged over 65. This is one of the highest proportions in the country. Current estimates are saying that in 2040 that is what Australia’s population will be like. That is many years away. Right here and now on the ground that is what we have got in Richmond. So we are seeing first-hand the needs of an ageing population and indeed how desperate those needs have become. In AprilI held an aged care summit, for the very reason that people were approaching me daily about their concerns, particularly in relation to the lack of home care within the Richmond electorate. People were saying that they would be assessed for home care and would have to wait sometimes eight, nine or 10 months. Let us just take a moment to look at these MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Ms Hall
theText: No. The member for Dobell does not seem to support the after-hours service
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mrs Elliot (Richmond) (6.20 Pm)
theText: I, too, am very disappointed that the Minister forpeople. They have moved to this area and they have retired there. They often tend to not have a lot of family or community networks. One of the partners gets sick, they get assessed for home care and they have to sit at home waiting for those eight, nine or 10 months. In fact, most people are often told: ‘Look, there is just no federal funding, so you’ll just have to wait.’ What do these people do? What ends up happening, often, if they are lucky, is that a volunteer organisation is able to provide some sort of limited care. But at the end of the day you have many hundreds of elderly people sitting in their homes deteriorating day by day. I think, in this day and age, that is absolutely horrendous. As I say, this is what Australia’s population is going to be like in 35 years. We have got to get it right-on the ground, here and now, in Richmond-with our ageing population. I notice that 2,000 new dementia packages were announced in the budget, but that is nationally. It hardly touches the surface of what is desperately needed in this area. I want to comment on the 75 packages that were released not too long ago from Grafton to the border. We are talking about a huge area: the electorate of Richmond goes from Skennars Head to Tweed Heads and we have the highest proportion of elderly people, and they are not getting the packages they so desperately need. As I say, they wait eight, nine and 10 months. What sort of respect is that for elderly people who have worked all their lives, who have now retired, who have been assessed for this home care and who then have to wait this long period of time? Sometimes they are even waiting longer than this. I think our elderly deserve better and I would like to know from the Minister for Ageing why there was not more provision for home care from the federal government in areas like Richmond where we have the highest proportion of elderly people and where the need is so desperate. We have to make sure that we are providing for the elderly people in our society. Ms HALL (Shortland) (6.25 pm)-I have a couple of quick questions for the Minister for Ageing. I would like to join with the member for Richmond on the issue that she raised about the lack of HACC services for people living in the community of Lake Macquarie on the Central Coast. I ask the minister to consider extending those services so that there are more available. I note that more packages have been released, as the member for Richmond said, but I think that the minister needs to look at a strategy to encourage the service providers to deliver those packages to more outlying areas. Within the electorate of Shortland many of the providers are in the inner Newcastle area-this is in the Lake Macquarie part-and it is very difficult to find any providers at all in the outlying regions like Catherine Hill Bay and Nords Wharf. Similarly people living in the more outlying and difficult areas on the Central Coast are not serviced in the same way. The other issue I raise is respite. I note that the government has increased the time available for respite for people but I am not sure whether the minister is aware that in many areas throughout Australia, particularly in my electorate, it is very difficult to access respite beds. Therefore there needs to be a strategy put in place, not only extending the time but ensuring that people can access respite beds when they need them. Ms GILLARD (Lalor) (6.27 pm)-I have two more questions about the budget measures which require answer andquorum. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: The Deputy Speaker (Hon. Bk Bishop)
theText: I advise that the bells are ringing for adid not supply answers to these questions because they are of vital interest to Australians with lung cancer, epilepsy and depression and to those at risk of osteoporosis. One of the measures in the budget was the implementation of the Howard government’s election savings measure which was the 12.5 per cent benchmark pricing measure in respect of the PBS. My questions are these: will the Minister for Health and Ageing or the Minister for Ageing, who is at the table on his behalf-and if the Minister for Ageing is unable to do so will she procure an undertaking that the Minister for Health and Ageing will answer these questions-confirm that the Department of Health and Ageing did not have anything to do with costing the 12.5 per cent benchmark price changes under the PBS? Will the minister guarantee that no drugs other than the ones announced last Wednesday will be subject to a special patient contribution-that is, drugs beyond the four comprehended in last Wednesday’s press release? I refer to that press release, which announced the special patient contributions, in which the minister said that he had received expert advice that other PBS-listed drugs can be used in place of the four drugs that now have special patient contributions. Who provided this advice? When was it provided and will the minister release it? As patented drugs move to generics, there is a question about the way in which savings are catered for on the PBS. We have been advised-and this was a badge of honour worn by the minister’s department at Senate estimates-that the department have been in consultation with the drug industry about when branded drugs are going to move to generics in respect of the 12½ per cent pricing measure. Yet we had been told by them before the last election that they could not quantify such savings for the general costs of the PBS. My question is: why aren’t the savings from the statins, which everybody knows are coming off patent, and from the SSRI group of drugs, which everybody knows are coming off patent, factored into the expenditure forecasts of the PBS? Why is the department of health capable of forecasting and costing these savings for one budget purpose-that is, to support the Howard government’s election promise about 12½ per cent benchmark pricing-but not for the general purpose of accurately forecasting PBS spending and the potential for savings? Briefly, on the decision to take calcium tablets off the PBS, has any modelling been done on the impact of the removal of calcium tablets from the PBS on calcium tablet usage by people at risk of osteoporosis? Finally, will the minister guarantee that no other medicine will be delisted from the PBS without a recommendation of the PBAC? I am in a position to supply those questions to the minister at the table, the Minister for Ageing, in writing. Ms JULIE BISHOP (Curtin-Minister for Ageing) (6.31 pm)-The member for Lalor has produced a series of questions in writing. She has offered to produce more questions in writing. The undertaking I give to her is that I will pass the questions on to the Minister for Health and Ageing. I turn to the matters that the member for Shortland raised. In relation to afterhours GP services, we are working with New South Wales to establish after-hours GP clinics at the hospitals in Liverpool, Nepean and Lismore, and Wyong could be eligible for support from the Round the Clock Medicare election commitment. The minister would certainly be happy to have discussions with the New South Wales government in that regard. Both the member for Shortland and the member for Richmond raised Medicare offices. The Minister for Human Services, Minister Joe Hockey, is responsible for the Health Insurance Commission. The issue of when Medicare offices open and close obviously depends on local MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Ms Gillard
theText: It would be a breathtaking act of arrogance if the Howard governmentdemand, as that changes. I am happy to pass these issues on to Minister Hockey, as the minister responsible for the Health Insurance Commission. The member for Shortland also raised the issue of respite care. The Australian government introduced the National Respite for Carers Program. It currently has funding of about $130 million. In the last budget we announced further funding of $208 million specifically for respite care, directed to areas of need, including further respite for working carers. In other words, this is to give them more flexibility by having respite centres open before and after working hours. There are increased incentives for residential aged care providers to have respite places available and to increase the uptake of respite, because we find that not all providers are fully utilising the allocated respite. That is why the extra funding has been allocated in this budget. We have also increased the funding for overnight and cottage style respite, which will be welcome in all areas-metropolitan, outer metropolitan, rural and regional-and there is more funding for respite in rural and regional Australia through the multipurpose services. The issue of dental care was raised by the member for Richmond. Dental care is a matter for state and territory governments. It is not a matter for the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth’s role has been in supporting dental services through the private health insurance rebate, and that is also focusing on the needs of older Australians with the increasing private health rebate for people over the ages of 65 and 70. The member for Richmond also complained of the lack of aged care funding in her electorate. I thought that when I visited her electorate over the weekend for the very pleasant opening of an aged care home in Byron BayI was able to outline to her and to the community representatives present that, in fact, the Australian government has committed a great deal of funding to the Far North Coast region in which the electorate of Richmond lies. There has been a 50 per cent increase in the allocation of aged care places in the Far North Coast region. The national increase has been 33 per cent but in the Far North Coast, in response to the increasing numbers of people over the age of 70, there has been a 50 per cent increase even though the age cohort over 70 has increased by some 29 per cent. The member for Richmond must be aware that aged care planning allocations are made via an independent, objective arms-length process that involves local planning advisory committees who advise on special needs. It is done through the Department of Health and Ageing. In terms of the allocation of places, this government’s record is exemplary. From the period of 1996 to 2007, over 95,200 aged care places will have been allocated across Australia. The member for Richmond obviously was not in parliament in 1996. She would have been mightily embarrassed by the report of the Auditor-General that when Labor left office in 1996 there was a 10,000 place deficit. SoI do not think Labor members can come into this House with any integrity and complain about the allocation of aged care places when this government rectified the deficit and has now allocated some 95,200 places across Australia for the period 1996 to 2007. (Time expired) tion is that the proposed expenditure for the Health and Ageing portfolio be agreed to. Proposed expenditure agreed to. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: The Deputy Speaker ( Mr Lindsay)
theText: The time for the debate has expired. The quesForeign Affairs and Trade Portfolio Proposed expenditure, $3,062,330,000. whales beached themselves near Busselton in Western Australia. This incident prompted an extraordinary reaction from Australians from every walk of life. Over 1,500 locals donned their wetsuits and waded into the shallows to help rescue these stranded whales. Their efforts were rewarded with the successful return of the bulk of that pod to the open sea. This incident demonstrates the deep respect and affection which the Australian people have for these giants of the deep. Furthermore, it demonstrates the strong public interest in Australia in the conservation of the species. So it is worth taking this opportunity to reflect on what steps our fearless foreign minister has taken to protect these creatures. It is particularly timely to do so today, the first day of the 2005 annual meeting of the International Whaling Commission in Ulsan in South Korea. Regrettably, our foreign minister has been missing in action on this issue. We have seen a flurry of activity from the environment minister, Senator Campbell, over the last six weeks or so, largely I suspect in response to prompting from those of us on this side of the House and from those in the media. But we fear that this may prove to be an inadequate response if what we are concerned about is the ending of Japan’s abuse of the practice of so-called whaling for scientific purposes. Japan of course has made no secret of its whaling ambitions. Since the commercial whaling ban was first introduced in 1986, Japan has been building up its support base within the International Whaling Commission, and its efforts have hardly gone unnoticed. At every IWC meeting since 1986 Japan has proposed a motion to allow it to hunt whales commercially in the Pacific. Over the years the balance of support on this matter within the IWC has gradually changed from a majority in favour of keeping the ban to an approximate fifty-fifty split. Today, on this first day of the 2005 IWC meeting, we will see whether Japan has finally been able to stack out this meeting. Voting on procedural motions today should begin to reveal the final balance between the proand anti-whaling lobbies of the IWC. Japan may be getting very close to achieving a majority vote in support of a resumption of commercial whaling. But our concern, whether or not that occurs, is with what happens about Japan’s continued abuse of so-called scientific whaling in general. Under the IWC rules, a change to the moratorium on commercial whaling requires a 75 per cent majority of the meeting. The political reality is that a simple majority vote in favour of commercial whaling would be a serious setback for those wanting to bring an end to the slaughter of these magnificent beasts. Japanese whaling ambitions and its efforts to increase its influence on the IWC are of course not new. These have been looming for years. This is therefore a matter on which the government should have been working for years, just as the government of Japan has been working for years on this matter-not just for the past six weeks, when it became a public item of media attention. So today, on the day when the balance at the IWC is at risk of tipping in favour of the pro-whaling lobby for the first time or at least getting close to that, the question must be asked: what has the government done to counteract the influence of Japan and other prowhaling countries on the IWC over the past few years? We are in the ridiculous situation MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Rudd (Griffith) (6.36 Pm)
theText: Members may be aware that on 2 June 2005 a pod of 60where neighbours and good friends of Australia such as Kiribati, the Solomons, Tuvalu and now, as we discovered over the weekend, Nauru may well have joined Japan in the IWC to support the lifting of the commercial whaling ban. If that occurs-and it is still a big ‘if’, because we do not know the outcome of the vote-it would be a most disturbing development in terms of the effectiveness of Australian diplomacy in the south-west Pacific. With Nauru’s overnight announcement that it would be joining the IWC as part of the pro-whaling lobby, questions must be asked about the effectiveness of, in particular, Australia’s diplomatic efforts with that country. (Time expired) pm)-The member for Griffith-and I think the entire nation-is aware that Australia is strongly opposed to Japan’s plans to increase its scientific whaling effort. In fact, Australia is one of the leading organisations in advocating for the interests of this remarkable mammal. This includes our actions in our own immediate neighbourhood but also more broadly in our work through the International Whaling Commission. More than half of the IWC, including Australia, have refused to review the Japanese arrangements until an independent review of the original scientific whaling program of Japan has been undertaken. We have not ruled in or out any particular action, because at this stage the crucial thing, to which I think the member for Griffith was alluding, is diplomacy. Diplomacy is at this stage our most direct pathway for securing the best prospect for success. Our nation has been working with other like-minded countries to put pressure on the Japanese not only directly through their Ministry of Foreign Affairs but also through their fishing agencies-so at a diplomatic level and at a scientific level. Australia has also been urging other members of the IWC to cease this so-called scientific whaling. As you would know, Senator Campbell has done a remarkable job in directly approaching a number of Pacific island countries and European countries to lobby in support of our position. The Prime Minister and the foreign minister have directly written to their counterparts in the governments of a number of IWC member states, seeking support for our position on whaling. That work continues, including most recent representations in light of Nauru’s decision to join the IWC. SoI think it is a little unfair and disingenuous to say that nothing has been happening. There has been extensive effort going forward. We understand the diplomatic pressures that are being brought to bear on countries through Japan using levers such as aid projects and the like. We are mindful of that. Ordinarily we are partners with Japan on good governance, aid harmonisation and the like, but here we are on different sides of the argument. But absolutely no suggestion can be sustained that anything other than complete vigour is going into the Australian effort to support our position at the IWC. was considering joining the International Whaling Commission? Did Senator Campbell visit Nauru? Has the Australian foreign minister raised these matters with his counterpart in Nauru? What action was taken to influence and persuade Nauru to support Australia’s strong antiwhaling position? What representations has the government, at its broadest level, made to the government of Nauru? There is a larger question about Foreign Minister Downer’s role in the conduct of Australia’s diplomatic efforts in the IWC. What action has the foreign minister personally taken in support of Australia’s antiwhaling stance? Under questioning in Senate estimates two weeks ago, officials from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade illumiMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Billson (Dunkley
theText: Parliamentary Secretary (Foreign Affairs and Trade)) (6.41
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Rudd (Griffith) (6.44 Pm)
theText: When did the government first become aware that Naurunated us. When asked, the department was unable to point to any representations made by the foreign minister since the IWC meeting in 2004-not one. Senator Faulkner said: Thank you. Before the Prime Minister raised this issue on his visit to Japan from 20 to 21 April, are you aware of this issue being raised at the ministerial level at all? Ms Adams, who I believe is Ambassador for the Environment, replied: No, I am not aware of it being raised at ministerial level prior to the recent set of representations on the proposed increase of the so-called scientific whaling program. It would appear that Mr Downer has not even bothered to pick up the phone to call his Japanese counterpart about this issue. If he has, he has not made that public. It would appear that, when the foreign minister visited Japan, he did not raise it face to face with his Japanese counterpart during his visit to Japan between 21 and 23 March this year. We also have some illuminating revelations from Senate estimates. Senator Faulkner, a great friend to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in his role in Senate estimates, asked: Was the whaling issue raised by Minister Downer during that visit? Ms Morton replied: I do not recall that it was, no. Senator FAULKNER-It was not? Ms Morton-I do not believe so, no. Senator FAULKNER-It was not raised by the minister. Was it raised by officials during that visit? Ms Morton-Not to my knowledge. So there we have the minister, on this matter of deep concern to the Australian people, simply asleep at the wheel. The bottom line is that he was in Japan, in Tokyo. He was meeting with the Japanese government. He is the foreign minister of Australia. His departmental annual report says he has co-responsibility with the Minister for the Environment and Heritage for discharging Australia’s policy obligations in whaling policy around the world. And what does our fearless foreign minister do in Japan? I presume he had a great game of tennis-a bit of golf maybe, I am not quite sure-but did he actually engage in the whaling policy issue? I do not think so. In fact, Senate estimates confirms through departmental officials that he did no such thing. Let us go again to Senate estimates, where we have further interesting revelations on the government’s energetic efforts in defence of the world’s whaling population. Senator FAULKNER-Is it the foreign minister who is responsible for dealing with the Japanese on this? It is being handled by DFAT and the foreign minister, isn’t it? Campbell has been taking the lead on this. The Ambassador for the Environment has been a long standing position based in DFAT, but on all these matters the foreign minister takes a very close interest. Mind you, not close enough to actually raise this during his visit to Japan-that would be too close an interest-but Dr Raby, ever the loyal public servant, said that in fact the minister has a very close interest in whaling matters. Senator Faulkner asked: What is DFAT’s role? Now, there is a core and cutting question. Dr Raby said: DFAT’s role is to support the activities of Senator Campbell, to support the Ambassador for the EnvironmentMAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Dr Raby
theText: No, the lead agency is the Department of the Environment and Heritage, and Senatora DFAT appointeeand, as necessary and required through our diplomatic mission in Tokyo, to make representations. It seems that, despite the fact that this matter involved a major international meeting and the lobbying of foreign governments-all matters that clearly fall within the job description of the Minister for Foreign AffairsMr Downer has seen fit to outsource his responsibility on this to a junior minister in another portfolio. Bruce, you could have done a lot better than this. In fact, I would have been much happier had you taken up the cudgels on this matter instead of throwing it to the C team-namely, the minister for environment. Having made only half-hearted, last-minute efforts to save whales on the international stage-and then, largely in response to political pressure from the opposition and the mediawhat has the Howard government’s record been much closer to home? Let us look at the whole question of whaling in the Australian Whale Sanctuary. (Extension of time granted) With great fanfare, the Howard government proposed the establishment of an Australian whale protection zone in the Australian Antarctic waters. It established that under an act of the Australian parliament, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act 1999. Section 229 of that act makes it a criminal offence to take any action which leads to the death or injury of a whale within the Australian Whale Sanctuary. The offence is punishable by imprisonment of up to two years or a $110,000 fine. These are serious laws. The government has obviously seen fit to legislate in this parliament to protect Australia’s whale population. But what has happened since? When it became known that since 1999, Japanese whalers have taken out hundreds of whales in those waters and the matter was then brought to the Federal Court, what did the Australian government do through the Attorney General? One answer is that it did nothing; another answer is that it did a lot. What it did was effectively harpoon the case being brought by the Humane Society International to try and protect Australian whales in the self-proclaimed Australian Whale Sanctuary. The Humane Society International, HSI, launched proceedings in the Federal Court against the Japanese company Kyodo Senpaku Kaisha Ltd. It has asked the Federal Court of Australia for a ruling that the company’s actions are illegal. It has also asked the court for an injunction which would prohibit the further killing of whales in Australian waters. The bulk of HSI’s evidence against the company comes from the Japanese government’s own reports to the IWC on its scientific research program. HSI claims that the cruise reports of the Japanese Whale Research Program under Special Permit in the Antarctic, JARPA, indicate that, since 2000, the Japanese company the subject of the legal challenge has illegally killed over 400 whales within the Australian Whale Sanctuary. What was the Howard government’s response to this move by the humane society to enforce its own laws? Not only has the government refused to do its own job of enforcing Australian law; it has actually moved to block the Humane Society International’s attempts to do so. The Attorney-General, on behalf of the Howard government and presumably Foreign Minister Downer and Environment Minister Senator Campbell, made a submission to the Federal Court in which he argued: (1) that Australia’s sovereignty over the Australian Antarctic Territory and the adjacent maritime zones are not recognised by Japan; and (2) that Japan would consider any attempt by Australia to enforce Australian law in the Australian Antarctic Territory as a breach of international law. The Attorney-General admitted in his submission that, firstly, the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act has force in the AustraMAIN COMMITTEE lian Antarctic Territory, including against foreigners; and, secondly, the fact that foreign states do not recognise the law does not preclude the application of the law to nationals of that state. Nevertheless, the Attorney-General said that the government considers it ‘more appropriate to pursue diplomatic solutions in relation to the activities by foreign vessels’ off the Australian Antarctic Territory. In other words, the government says: ‘Yes, the Japanese are breaking Australian laws, and the fact that Japan does not recognise our sovereignty does not preclude us from taking action to enforce our laws, but we would prefer not to enforce our laws. We would rather use diplomacy instead.’ That diplomacy appears to be demonstrably failing. In other words-‘Oops! Sorry, we don’t want to offend the Japanese. We don’t want to create a diplomatic incident. We’re not about to enforce our own laws.’ This is a Howard government law to protect a Howard government proclaimed Australian Whale Sanctuary, established under a Howard government act of parliament. Their response to the Australian people has been that they are too weak to do anything about it. Frankly, it is pathetic. It is more than pathetic; it involves a level of deception as well. On 27 May, the Federal Court in Sydney confirmed what we would argue as being the Howard government’s hypocritical response to the slaughter of whales in the Australian Whale Sanctuary adjacent to Antarctica. The Howard government’s intervention in the case caused the court to refuse permission to the Humane Society International to proceed against Japanese whaling companies. Specifically, the Federal Court cited the intervention of the Attorney-General, Mr Ruddock, who argued that to enforce Australian law against the Japanese company ‘would be likely to give rise to international disagreement with Japan’. Labor’s calls for the government to take action against Japan in the International Court of Justice have only been reinforced by the decision of the Federal Court. Our view now is that, because of the difficulties this case has run into, we need to take the legal challenge to Japan to a new level. We say that, given what has occurred in the Federal Court, the only available jurisdiction to bring about the proper protection for whales world wide is for an appropriate action to be taken in the International Court of Justice. (Extension of time granted) You see, what happened with the Federal Court matter was this: we had an Australian government proclaimed law concerning the Australian Antarctic Territory waters, within which was proclaimed an Australian Whale Sanctuary, and the government said, ‘Well, we can’t really enforce that law because there’s not sufficient international legal recognition of Australia’s sovereignty claim in that area.’ Isn’t that a problem at the very time you proclaim the Australian Whale Sanctuary in the first place? If you thought in 1999 it was a bogus proposition, why did you do it? Why did you put out the press releases? Why did you try and claim the political credit? If you thought back then it was unenforceable, why go through the great political song-and-dance routine of pretending that it is real? This is an extraordinary matter. The argument, however, that the government put in submissions was that Australian law does apply in these areas, including in relation to foreign vessels-and it is time the government got serious about this. That is why we think the only course of action available is an appropriate action before the ICJ. The scientific research exemption on the international whaling convention provides an opportunity for Japanese whalers to flout the ban on commercial whaling. We believe that there may well be a strong case under international law that Japan is not acting in good faith or in accordance with its treaty obligations under the International Convention for the Regulation MAIN COMMITTEE of Whaling, 1946. In support of this proposition we would point to an article by professor of international law Gillian Triggs. The article was published in the Asia Pacific Journal of International Law 2000 and explored the possibility of taking Japan to the ICJ on the basis that its hunting of whales for scientific purposes constitutes an abuse of rights. In summary, the basis of a possible claim would be that Japan is abusing its permit to kill whales for scientific purposes and that this is not in accordance with the intention of the IWC treaty. The doctrine of the abuse of rights is essentially an extension of the principle that rights must be exercised in good faith-in other words, that a right must be exercised for the purpose for which it exists, not to undermine that purpose. In other words, a right granted under a treaty must not be used for the purpose of evading an obligation under that treaty. The doctrine of the abuse of rights has recently been recognised in the shrimp-turtle case, in which the WTO appellate body found that a state must exercise its treaty rights reasonably and in a bona fide matter and that, while the state may invoke an exception allowed in a treaty, a balance must be achieved between the exercise of that exceptional right and the treaty rights of other parties. Professor Triggs in her article sets out the possible case against Japan. As a member of the IWC, Japan has voluntarily agreed to be bound by the international convention on whaling, which prohibits the killing of whales for commercial use. Japan’s hunting of whales is conducted under an exemption to that treaty which allows for special permits to be granted for the killing of whales for scientific purposes. It is argued that Japan, through its use of this exemption, is not acting for scientific purposes as required but instead using the exemption to procure whales for commercial sale, which is prohibited under the convention. It is therefore argued that Japan is not acting in good faith and is in fact abusing this right in order to evade its treaty obligations under the convention to observe the moratorium on commercial whaling. It is further argued that Japan’s evasion of its treaty obligations undermines the legitimate interests of other states party to the IWC which have a legitimate interest in the moratorium on commercial whaling being honoured. It is basically a matter of degrees. To make out the case, Australia would need to demonstrate that the primary purpose of the permit was other than for scientific research. While Japan would be able to show that the permits are used for scientific research, Australia could call its bona fides into doubt if it could demonstrate, for example, that the research (1) has little scientific value, (2) could be conducted without actually killing whales, (3) could be conducted by the killing of a smaller number of whales or (4) is insignificant when compared with the commercial uses to which whale meat is put. This particular legal opinion has in fact been made available during a year 2000 IWC meeting in Adelaide by a DFAT legal officer. I quote the verbatim transcript of the IWC meeting, where the Australian legal representative supplied by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade says: ... Mr Chairman, I would now like to bring to the attention of the Commission some recent developments in international legal practice and precedent which for many international lawyers raise the possibility that Japan might not be acting properly within its legal rights when it issues scientific permits. That is the department of foreign affairs legal representative at an International Whaling Commission meeting in Adelaide in the year 2000. That is not the Australian Labor Party speaking. That is not the international antiwhaling movement speaking. That is DFAT’s own MAIN COMMITTEE legal officer sending a shot across the bow, so to speak, of Japan’s whaling interest. (Extension of time granted.) The department admitted that it had taken legal advice on whaling issues and refused to confirm or deny whether an action in the ICJ was being considered, saying no option had been ruled out, whether diplomatic or legal. In summary, looking at the whaling issue as a whole, what we have seen is a range of failures on the part of the government to properly protect whales. Firstly, we have seen what appears to be a very laggardly approach by the government in the prosecution of its diplomatic relationships in the South Pacific and elsewhere in the world in the lead-up to this meeting of the IWC in South Korea. Secondly, we have seen the whole question of the government’s intervention in the court case in the Federal Court brought by Humane Society International. Thirdly, we have seen a government so timorous in its approach to this question that it has refused so far to countenance taking this matter to the International Court of Justice, despite having flagged the possibility of such an action in a legal opinion that was presented to the IWC meeting in Adelaide in 2000. When it comes to the proper protection of whales our challenge to the Howard government is very simple. In plain spoken English, it is simply this: get real, cut to the chase, do something that will actually cause the end of this abuse of so-called scientific whaling by Japan around the world-not just in Australian Antarctic Territory waters, not just in our own part of the world, but worldwide. The best way to do that is through a focused legal action before the ICJ in order to bring this unacceptable slaughter of the world’s whale population to a close. be very brief. I would appreciate some advice on one issue from the parliamentary secretary. That issue is the ECP, which is regarded by both sides of the parliament as a key program in Australia’s involvement with and relationship to Papua New Guinea. As you would be aware just recently the Supreme Court of Papua New Guinea ruled key elements of the program-or the legislation in relation to the police component of the program-unconstitutional. It would be helpful to get advice from the parliamentary secretary about what steps are now being taken to get the key elements and the core goals of the program back on track. It would also be helpful to get some explanation from the parliamentary secretary about what contributed to the failures of the arrangements to date. I note, for example, that on 16 May the foreign minister when asked to comment on the supreme court’s ruling was quoted as saying, ‘We were not involved.’ That position has been directly contradicted by the foreign minister of Papua New Guinea, Sir Rabbie Namaliu, who said: A statement by the Australian Foreign Minister ... that Australia was not involved ... was both unfortunate and incorrect ... The suggestion that somehow Australia was in the dark when it came to the final ECP legislation is totally ... incorrect. The police minister, Bire Kimisopa, made the following comment: These are things that both governments, the Australian government and the PNG government, knew very well. We are talking here about in excess of $1 billion of Australian taxpayers’ money over five years, and yet it would appear that the foreign minister in particular has treated issues related to the constitutionality of the program in a most cavalier manner. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Sercombe (Maribyrnong) (7.01 Pm)
theText: I am aware that time is very limited so I willpm)-I will go first to the member for Griffith’s comments. As I made clear in an earlier contribution, the government have not ruled out any legal or diplomatic avenues to bring pressure to bear on Japan. I thought we had made that point quite clear. In relation to the court action he was referring to, the Attorney-General’s submission did what you would hope all lawyers would do and that was point out frankly and clearly the practical difficulties associated with enforcing Australian law against foreign nationals in the EEZ off the Australian Antarctic Territory-a point that the Federal Court recognised. In relation to other avenues, as I have mentioned we have not ruled out any legal or diplomatic options, and I have characterised the spread of diplomatic overtures. But even on the doctrine of abuse of rights, where one may argue that scientific whaling permits are in breach of rights, you need a scientific basis to argue that case. As I mentioned earlier, that is why Australia, together with about half the other countries that send delegates to the IWC, is arguing for an independent review of Japan’s original scientific whaling program. One needs evidence in order to support any argument one may mount if it is to work going forward. The foreign minister has also written to the President of Nauru, Ludwig Scotty, and Foreign Affairs Minister, David Adeang. At this stage it is unclear whether the delegation would attend the IWC meeting, but it appears as though they will and that is another avenue for advocacy. I turn quickly to the member for Maribyrnong. He and I share a concern that the setback regarding the Wenge decision in Papua New Guinea has taken some momentum out of the program, out of the ECP. The foreign minister met with the PNG Foreign Minister and the Minister for Internal Security on 26 May, and I think there was a shared commitment to finding a way forward. Senior officials also met in Port Moresby on 9 and 10 June to examine possible solutions. The discussions have been constructive. A range of possible avenues are being canvassed, given the complexity of the court ruling. (Extension of time granted) Given the strong commitment on both sides to finding a way forward, a range of avenues are being canvassed. One is how to find a solution that will maintain the ECP in its current form and protect it from future legal challenges. There is some interest in whether a constitutional amendment is warranted, and that is a subject that is being discussed as not the preferred pathway. But the Wenge decision gives rise to diplomatic immunity available to all foreign nationals. Through you, Mr Chairman, to the member for Maribyrnong, I think that is resonating with some of the people in Port Moresby-that it is one thing to deal with the ECP; it is another thing, in light of that court decision, to provide for appropriate immunities for foreign government representation in that country. That is not a dead duck, if I can put it that way, but it is certainly not straightforward either. The other avenue being canvassed is whether some amendment to the PNG legislation is another pathway, but that may still leave some residual issues to be resolved. The last point related to the Australian government’s awareness of the PNG legislation. In June 2004, officials provided some suggested text to assist the PNG draft the legislation. PNG took responsibility for its own legislation but took on board those drafting suggestions. I am aware of some concerns that some PNG officials had about constitutional inconsistencies. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

I am not sure whether the parliamentary secretary can answer that-that is, regarding the decision of cabinet. Also, how does this decision reconcile with comments made by the Deputy Prime Minister on 11 April 2005 in a press release titled ‘2004: A record year for airlines’? In that media release, he said the following: Competition is alive and well in Australia’s skies with more Australians flying than ever before ... And: ... the industry has rebounded to be more robust and more productive than ever ... I know there is a series of questions there for the parliamentary secretary, but they are really just in two lots and are about the decisions being made by cabinet and the views of the government in terms of how they are going to deal with those and whether they will make those public. speaker: Mr Ripoll
theText: I hope the parliamentary secretary has a very fast pen or a very good memI also want to raise an issue that is very important to my electorate in south-east Queensland: the festering sore which is the Ipswich Motorway, particularly in relation to the full upgrade of the Ipswich Motorway. Now we have the completed report-the final report, we all hope-which is entitled the Ipswich Motorway northern option feasibility report. My question to the minister, through the parliamentary secretary, is: when will the government announce that it will proceed with the full upgrade of the Ipswich Motorway, in light of this further and final report? This independent report was released by the engineering firm Maunsell following a feasibility study of the Ipswich Motorway upgrade and the half-northern bypass. Can the minister confirm when the go-ahead will be given? Can he also tell us, in terms of what is there now, what the government’s next move will be? A lot was said during the election campaign about $627 million being on the table. We now know that that money was promised in many different areas-it was the same bucket of money. I have a quote from the Prime Minister where he said that, for the Ipswich Motorway corridor-which would be the Ipswich Motorway road and, if you wanted to include it, the northern option as well-$627 million was on the table and available right now. When will the money be forthcoming? When will it be spent? When will we get some resolution in terms of the Ipswich Motorway upgrade? liamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services relate to the administration of the Regional Partnerships program; I know the parliamentary secretary is involved in the administration of that program. Given the lavish advertising budgets of the Howard government, particularly in election years, it could be remarked on as a rather surprising fact that no advertising campaigns have been conducted to promote or encourage funding applications for the Regional Partnerships program. Since the increased budget allocations in 2005-06, this program is a half a billion dollar program. It has been about bolstering the government in target electorates. It has become rather better known, as a result of the opposition’s scrutiny of the government’s pork-barrelling, than it was before. When the program was launched, there were no as on TV, no as on radio and no as in the newspapers. The government did not write to Labor or other non-government MPs telling us about the program and how constituents of non-government electorates could make funding applications. So my question to the parliamentary secretary is: can he advise whether the department prepared a communications strategy for the Regional Partnerships program, including things like letters to MPs to explain the purpose of the program and to provide information for the Australian community? Indeed, was the department only tasked to prepare letters to government members of parliament, providing information about the program? Has it become standard practice under the Howard government to differentiate between government MPs and non-government MPs in providing advice on programs distributing taxpayers’ funds? It has also emerged from scrutiny of the government’s regional programs in the House and from the Senate inquiry into the Regional Partnerships program that there was a set of guidelines which applied to some but not all grants-the so-called Strategic Opportunities Notional Allocation or SONA guidelines. I have a number of questions concerning these guidelines. Is it correct that these guidelines were kept secret from the public? Is it correct that chairs of area consultative committees were not advised of their existence? Is it also correct that spending MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Kelvin Thomson (Wills) (7.13 Pm)
theText: The questions I want to raise with the Paron projects under these secret guidelines blew out from an expected $3 million last financial year to $21 million? Is it correct that projects that fell outside the public Regional Partnerships guidelines could be approved under SONA guidelines but that prospective applicants were never made aware of this and so may have been deterred from lodging applications? The Deputy Prime Minister, under the heat of the opposition’s scrutiny, has refused reasonable information requests from the Senate inquiry. This does not bode particularly well for the transparency and accountability of this government post July 1. In particular, the government has refused to release all area consultative committee advice on Regional Partnerships applications across the board. Yet it selectively releases area consultative committee advice to back up some of its funding decisions that have been queried-for example, the Deputy Prime Minister tabled on 2 December last year the RM Williams centre funding application. How does the government justify this lack of transparency? Has the department been directed to withhold this information by the minister? I think the processes of the department require further scrutiny. We see that some applications lodged by area consultative committees under the Regional Partnerships program were not processed for up to nine months while 12 projects were approved within 24 hours of the applications being made. I also refer the parliamentary secretary to the department’s evidence to the Senate inquiry that in a number of applications, including the $4.95 million grant to the University of New England, the minister explicitly asked the department to bring the application forward as quickly as possible. On how many occasions did this happen and why did the minister ask for some projects to be brought forward and not others? Another point about the evidence to the Senate inquiry into Regional Partnerships is that the department advised that the decision making minister-in most cases parliamentary secretary Mrs Kelly-on 11 occasions approved grants that the department recommended be rejected, on three occasions approved full funding for projects the department proposed should receive a lesser amount and in three cases rejected a project the department recommended be approved. (Extension of time granted) Will details of those projects and the reason that the minister ignored the departmental recommendations in each of those cases be provided to the parliament? In my book they certainly should be. I would appreciate responses from the parliamentary secretary on these issues. swer the questions I will ask on behalf of my electorate of Lowe in relation to aircraft noise. I want to inform the parliamentary secretary, that I was elected to this place on this very issue. My predecessor was a member of the Howard government and in January 1998 resigned in disgust because the Prime Minister was not prepared to back his local member in relation to the excessive amounts of aircraft noise over the electorate of Lowe and indeed the inner west of Sydney. I have spoken on this issue more often than any other during my 6½ years in this House. It is a very important issue for my electorate. But I am very concerned that the Deputy Prime Minister is behaving very arrogantly in response to the innumerable questions that I have placed on the Notice Paper and the speeches that I have made in this House. I want to highlight for the parliamentary secretary some of the questions that I have raised since 2002, to give him some insight into this issue. Since 27 May 2002, there has been a mantra by the Deputy Prime Minister in answer to my questions, which are serious questions. The mantra has been: MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Murphy (Lowe) (7.19 Pm)
theText: I regret that the minister is not here this evening to anI have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member. I will give you a taste. I asked the Deputy Prime Minister on 27 May 2002, for the umpteenth time: ... will he guarantee the people of Sydney that the long term lease of Sydney Airport will not be sold until the Long Term Operating Plan is fully implemented; if not, why not. And: Can and will the LTOP be implemented before Sydney Airport is sold; if not, why not. I have just told you what his response to that question was. I asked the Deputy Prime Minister another question two days later: Further to the reply to question No. 27... , how is the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) for Sydney Airport substantially implemented in terms of the LTOPs 17% forecast targets for air traffic movements to and from the north of Sydney Airport. And what was the answer I got? The Deputy Prime Minister answered: I have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member. On 25 June 2002 I asked: Is it a fact that the motions to implement the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) fully for Sydney Airport passed by the Sydney Airport Community Forum have not been met by Airservices Australia. And: Will he direct Airservices Australia to implement fully the LTOP for Sydney Airport forthwith; if not, why not. And what do you think he replied? I am very pleased to see that the member for Grayndler is in this chamber because he too has spoken more often on this issue than on any other topic in relation to his electorate. The arrogant response I got from the minister to my question was as follows: I have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member. A day later I asked another question of the minister, inter alia: Is it also a fact that the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) cannot be sustained for an indefinite period because (a) the only air traffic modes that enable Sydney Airport to reach 80 movements per hour are those modes that revert to parallel runway operations and (b) in reaching 80 aircraft movements per hour, only parallel runway use can be expected when the airport approaches that ultimate capacity. And: If he allows Sydney Airport to reach the ultimate capacity of 80 movements per hour over 17 hours, will Sydney residents, especially those to the north of the airport, be exposed to the noise impacts of parallel runway operations at Sydney Airport every day, that is, approximately 700 landings per day and 700 take offs per day. What do you think the answer was? It was: I have dealt with these matters exhaustively in response to questions previously asked by the Honourable member. On 26 June 2002 I also asked: MAIN COMMITTEE In light of the SACF Chairpersons media comments, can the LTOP targets for total aircraft movements to the north, east and west of Sydney Airport ever be achieved in light of prevailing meteorological and other environmental factors; if so, when and how will those targets be achieved. And: Are the LTOP targets reasonable in light of the scientific data relied upon at the time the LTOP was made; if so, why is it that the LTOP targets have never been achieved in the history of its implementation. And: Why does the LTOP continue to be asserted as the answer to Sydney Airports aircraft noise problems, when the people residing to the north of the airport, especially those residents living in the electoral division of Lowe, continue to have their noise sharing and respite hopes dashed by perpetually unmet LTOP targets. (Extension of time granted) The minister replied: I have dealt with these matters exhaustively ... I know the member for Grayndler is anxious to contribute, and I will allow him to, because I am sure he wants to speak on this very issue. I will truncate my contribution by drawing attention to my question on 26 June 2002, where I got a similar response from the minister, and to my questions on 27 June 2002, 28 August 2002, 14 October 2002, 5 June 2003, 11 August 2003, 19 August 2003, 2 December 2003, 24 March 2004 and 17 November 2004. It goes on and on and on, and all we get is a dishonest response from the minister. By way of finality, I turn to a second issue: why have the government decided that over the next 20 years there is no requirement for a second airport for the people of Sydney and of New South Wales? That is outrageous. Quite plainly the government have said they are more interested in looking after Macquarie Bank and the Southern Cross consortium, who bought the airport in the interests of their shareholders, and in making sure that Sydney airport operates as a shopping centre and a car park and not an airport. that it would review Sydney’s airport needs in 2005. The time has come. However, thanks to the member for Batman’s question on notice, it has been revealed that the government has breached its commitment to review Sydney’s airport needs in 2005. Indeed, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services continues to cling to his flawed master plan as an explanation for the government’s inaction on Sydney airport. The minister for transport approved the Sydney airport master plan on 22 March 2004. The plan claims that Kingsford Smith is able to cope with increased traffic over the next 20 years, yet the plan projects a 180 per cent increase in the number of aircraft movements at Sydney airport-from 225,200 movements per year in 2001-02 to 412,000 movements per year by 2023-24. Further, the next 20 years will see a tripling of passengers, from 23 million to 68 million. The plan denies that this dramatic increase in traffic will result in an eventual removal of the curfew and movement cap. The reality is that already movements are seriously encroaching on these curfew periods. A recent Airservices Australia report indicated that the number of aircraft movements increased by nine per cent between January 2002 and January 2005. Residents in and around my electorate are suffering the bulk of this increase, along with those in the member for Lowe’s electorate. As the number of movements increase at the airport, the concentration is increased to the north. This is the most densely populated area of Sydney. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Albanese (Grayndler) (7.25 Pm)
theText: In the year 2000, the Howard government saidThe residents of Sydenham, St Peters and Marrickville are being subjected to between 13 and 18 more flights per day that exceed the 70 decibel level-that is, the level at which conversations are interrupted and watching television or listening to the radio becomes impossible. Such a significant increase over the past three years alone highlights the undeniable falsehoods of the master plan. Claims that Sydney airport can cope alone are dishonest and misleading. I draw the House’s attention once again to the issue of Fort Street High School. The fact that kids have their education disrupted up to every three minutes by low-flying aircraft is an outrage. It should be addressed, and that school should be insulated. You do not have different hearing according to your wealth. The fact is that some schools have been insulated around the site. Taverners Hill Infants School, 200 metres down the road, has been insulated but Fort Street missed out. The government should fix it. It is playing politics with people’s futures, and young people deserve better. There must be a mandatory enforcement of the curfew and the movement cap. International flights at KSA continue to be scheduled to land outside of the 6 am and 11 pm curfew period. These are scheduled flights. This morning a British Airways flight, BA15 from London, landed at 5.05 am. In all, 10 international flights landed this morning before 6 am. Seven flights are scheduled to breach the curfew tomorrow morning between 5 am and 6 am. Freight flights also continue to be granted dispensations to land outside of the curfew period. The use and abuse of the so-called shoulder period continues to inflict aircraft noise on communities that already suffer considerably during the non-curfew periods. Just last month I informed the House about a low-flying jet which created a vortex that lifted 100 tiles from the roof of a residence in my electorate-this is the kind of impact aircraft are having on residents in my electorate. This is a practical reality of living in Sydenham in 2005. Instead of reviewing and addressing these issues, as previously committed, the government has instead approved an outrageous expansion of Sydney airport’s commercial facilities with no regard for the fact that $1.8 billion of extra infrastructure will be required. Twelve-storey car parks and tower blocks of shops, hotels and offices are instead the minister’s plans for the airport. The minister is ignoring the ever-increasing crisis of aircraft noise in Sydney’s inner west and is instead creating one of increased traffic and congestion on the ground. The minister has not paid a single visit to a school, a nursing home, a church or a community organisation around the airport. He has shown contempt since he became the minister-unlike, I might say, Mark Vaile and John Sharp, his predecessors, who both came to the electorate and had a look first-hand. This is a minister who has shown contempt. Whatever Max Moore-Wilton wants simply goes at Sydney airport. It is unacceptable. (Time expired) Ms Hall-There are more questions. There are more speakers. vice. The chair is well aware of what is what. For the information of the parliamentary secretary, I misled you earlier: this debate can go on for as long as is needed. firmation of the government’s intention with regard to the Ipswich Motorway northern option. I now have a comparison, and I want to put on the record that comparison between the two options. The full upgrade of the Ipswich Motorway would provide a full upgrade along the entire 19 kilometres of the motorway. It would cost $1.1 billion, which includes $160 million for the Logan interchange upgrade. This equates to around $57 million per kilometre. In terms MAIN COMMITTEE

speaker: Mr Ripoll (Oxley) (7.31 Pm)
theText: I want to add to a question I asked earlier and seek conof timing, the planning has been finalised, and, if construction were started today, the full upgrade could be completed by the end of 2009. In terms of construction, it can be done in stages to minimise traffic disruption. The Goodna-Gailes section could be completed by 2008 and only five per cent of construction would be done under traffic, with some sections of the motorway realigned completely. With regard to the long-term benefits of upgrading the Ipswich Motorway, it is designed to cater for traffic flow for more than 20 years and would deliver six lanes for through traffic along an entire route, as well as a series of local and service roads to cater for local traffic. That means a network of between 10 and 17 lanes. Compare that, Parliamentary Secretary, with the half-bypass option. It is only eight kilometres of road. It would cost about the same sort of money-$1.1 billion-but would exclude the $160 million for the Logan interchange upgrade. That equates to around $142 million per kilometre. In terms of timing, a minimum of another three years of planning would be required before design and construction could begin, in mid-2009, and the project would not be completed before 2012. Given that the Ipswich Motorway is part of the national highway network, funding for any maintenance and construction activity rests with the federal government. When will the minister announce that the project will go ahead, and provide the money that everyone from the PM down during the last federal election campaign promised was on the table? Do we now, after all, find that that was not the truth-that there is no money allocated for this project? Can the minister either confirm or deny that? When will the minister stop misleading the people of south-east Queensland and actually get on with the job of fixing the road? Perhaps the parliamentary secretary would attempt to answer a couple of questions. Firstly, in relation to the Namoi structural adjustment fund criteria, could the parliamentary secretary outline the processes involved in obtaining funding from the Namoi structural adjustment fund, with particular reference to the two zeolite mines which are within that catchment area within the Gwydir electorate. Could he explain why one zeolite mine has been funded to the competitive disadvantage of another zeolite mine; and how that fits with the processes of application for funding that have come out of the Namoi structural adjustment package? The other question I will ask the parliamentary secretary relates to a story in the Northern Daily Leader of 21 September 2004. I understand that the parliamentary secretary will probably be unable to answer this, but I think the minister in question really should answer it. In a story on 21 September 2004 in the Northern Daily Leader the Mayor of Tamworth, Councillor James Treloar, was quoted as saying: The $6 millionwhich was for the equine centre, which the parliamentary secretary is well aware ofis coming from the Federal Government’s Regional Partnerships Program and even if the Labor Party won next month’s Federal election, the money would still be there. The story went on to say: ... the announcement about the funding had been made possible before the October9 election because the application, plans and financial details had been submitted by the Australian Equine and Livestock Centre about a month ago … So that was just prior to the calling of the election. According to the Mayor of Tamworth: MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Windsor (New England) (7.33 Pm)
theText: I am disappointed that the minister is not here.This meant that the government could allocate the $6 million and not be tainted by accusations of pork barrelling. If, as the story in the Northern Daily Leader tells us, everything had been received by the department and the minister, so that it was possible to make an ironclad announcement during the election campaign, why did the Tamworth Regional Council have to submit further information for analysis earlier this year? If it was not the case that everything had been received, why didn’t the Deputy Prime Minister or the department correct the inaccuracy in the Northern Daily Leader story? In addition, why has the Deputy Prime Minister asserted that funding for the equine centre, particularly given this preamble, was held up by the Senate inquiry into the Regional Partnerships Program? time, I would like to make a very short contribution to this debate and take the opportunity to put some very specific questions to the parliamentary secretary. I would invite him to answer them tonight if he can, but if he cannot do so I would certainly request that he take them on notice and get back to me at a later date. My questions involve three road projects in my electorate. The first is the proposed link between the F3 freeway and the New England Highway north of Branxton, sometimes colloquially known as the Kurri corridor; the second is the Weekley’s Drive intersection; and the third is the Muswellbrook bypass. All of those three projects were part of what was known, I suppose, as the national highway project, and all are projects that have been on the drawing board for some time. Indeed, all three projects had financial commitments from the Commonwealth prior to the 1996 election. I have to say I find the budget documents increasingly difficult to read. I say that with no embarrassment whatsoever, because I think making them increasingly difficult to read is a deliberate ploy on the part of the government. I know with respect to the Kurri corridor that there was a $250 million commitment in the AusLink program, but my understanding is that there is no commitment to the Kurri corridor-or the F3 link-in the forward estimates, and I specifically ask the minister to clarify whether that is the case. If there is no commitment in the forward estimates, where does the $250-odd million now stand; is it entirely dependent on an agreement yet to be reached with the New South Wales government; and when does the parliamentary secretary expect any such agreement to be met? The second project I wish to find out about is the Weekley’s Drive intersection. It is a project whose cost ranges between some $25 million and $35 million, depending on what treatment is embraced eventually by the Commonwealth, in consultation with the state. Again, this is a project which is now 10 years overdue. The Commonwealth seems to be blaming the state for holding up design on the project. The state advises me that that is not true and that in fact the Commonwealth has been seeking to embrace a cheaper design, which the RTA in New South Wales says is not up to speed for the proper treatment of that intersection in safety terms. SoI invite the parliamentary secretary to make some comment on that. The third project is the Muswellbrook bypass, a much needed bypass for that particular town. Again, that is a project that has been on the drawing board and has been much discussed since prior to the 1996 election. It seems to now be in limbo. I welcome any response that the parliamentary secretary can give me on that particular project. MAIN COMMITTEE
title: Appropriation Bill No 1 2005 2006

speaker: Mr Fitzgibbon (Hunter) (7.37 Pm)
theText: IfI could take two minutes of the chamber’sgional Services) (7.40 pm)-There was a fair list of questions there. I will try to take them one at a time. Most of them. I will refer on but some I will answer myself. The member for Grayndler raised some issues about airlines and the public time frame for the review et cetera. I will refer those to the minister, and we will get back to him on those questions, including the aircraft noise issues which he brought up. With regard to the member for Oxley, the only thing I will mention specifically is the Ipswich Motorway. I think he mentioned a figure of $650 million and indicated that it was all available straight away. That is actually not so. Under the AusLink package, $627 million was available over the first five-year investment for improvements to that road’s infrastructure and the urban Brisbane corridor. A significant amount out of those funds has already been committed to upgrading works along the Ipswich Motorway. That includes the preconstruction and design of a new $160 million interchange at the junction of the Ipswich and Logan motorways, which is also the highest priority work in Queensland’s six-lane proposal, and the implementation of a range of safety works and further planning along the Ipswich Motorway, valued at around $66 million. Mr Hardgrave interjectingback to him on those, including those about aircraft noise. The member for Wills wanted to talk about Regional Partnerships and he raised the question of due process. There is only one process for Regional Partnerships. He also asked if we advertise. The area consultative committees around Australia, all 50 of them, have budgets. They make provision in their budgets to publicise what they do and how they do it. They get the information out to community organisations, to local government councils, to small business and to anyone who might have an opportunity to make use of Regional Partnerships. It is their job, not the government’s, to make known around Australia what is available in that sense and how it is done. At various times we put out certain press releases on the program, but we do not advertise as a government about Regional Partnerships. As a matter of fact, the opposition has probably done a better job of advertising how much good Regional Partnerships does; we have not needed to do it. I can assure the honourable member that all the area consultative committees right around Australia get a budget commensurate with the size of their region and commensurate with the number of employees they need. It is their job to publicise the benefits of the program to people, to organisations, to local government, to state government and to individual businesses. The government do not do that; they do. The member for Wills also mentioned the SONA program. It is not a secret program. There are no secret instructions given to ACCs, the department or anyone else. In that context, he brought up the national centre for maths, science and information technology at the University of New England and the status of that project. It established a national centre for mathematics, science and information technology for rural and regional education. The project he referred to involves a hub at UNE and training applications around Australia. Nobody can apply for a Regional Partnerships grant under the SONA procedures. It is a strategic element of Regional Partnerships. It is used to fund projects of high national significance that may fall outside the administrative constraints of Regional Partnerships. The member for Wills seemed to be indicating that something secret goes on. It does not. There is no MAIN COMMITTEE

Basically, this government had two different proposals, both were about an equine centre and both were to be sited at Tamworth. The original proposal put up in 2001 wanted $3½ million towards a proposed $21 million to $24 million project. That was provided to Professor John Chudleigh for an independent review-as to whether it was a goer, in effect. Advice to government was that it was not. Further work was done on this proposal, taking into account Professor Chudleigh’s findings, and a second proposal was provided to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Minister Anderson, in 2004. The second proposal had very serious key changes that did address all the concerns raised by Professor Chudleigh. There was a review of the scale of the original proposal and a minor relocation to take into account an existing exhibition facility, saving an estimated $10 million. The original proposal in 2001 and the one announced by the minister were like chalk and cheese. The first was pie in the sky; the second was a serious proposal with management costs and the whole lot done. theText: Minister for Vocational and Technical Education and Mintion for the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference, the APEC conference, in 2007. There were some minor offsets to deal with the Office for the Status of Women being transferred to Family and Community Services; the finalisation of task forces from 2004-05; and some other minor increases. But essentially the increase that you see before you in the consideration of this bill in detail has come from the government’s commitment to what we will be working very hard to achieve-that is, a very successful APEC in 2007. me if it is not-to congratulate the Prime Minister and the state premiers on a recent initiative. At a recent Council of Australian Governments meeting, significant priority was given for the first time to the issue of young people with disabilities who are currently ‘inappropriately’ housed. I would like to place on record my congratulations to all of those involved-to the Prime Minister, who led the delegation, and to the states-for recognising those who need a little more help than they have perhaps been getting in the past. I do not mean that that is the fault of anybody, but I think there is growing recognition that people with disabilities are going to grow older than they used to, in the majority of cases, and that in many cases they are inappropriately housed and require other services so that they can be more appropriately cared for. I would urge the minister in the chair to convey my thanks to the Prime Minister but also to encourage the Prime Minister and those in the appropriate portfolios to really take this issue forward and address it. It is not one that will be terribly expensive to address in terms of the budgetary processes in total, but in my view, and I think in the view of many, it is an issue that really passes judgment on us as a parliament and on Australians as a society, as to how we care for people who have disabilities. ister Assisting the Prime Minister) (8.03 pm)-I assure the member for New England and indeed this chamber that I certainly will make known to the Prime Minister his comments and his encouragement. There is no doubt that the edge of disagreement between the states and the Commonwealth on matters to do with disability causes an enormous amount of hurt and frustration to individual people. We find it awfully frustrating to see the states always retreating from the ground that we try to move onto, leaving further ground for us to have to accommodate certain aspects. Along the way, it is often the case that individual people are the ones who miss out. I have plenty in my electorate, and I have had to say to previous state disabilities ministers, ‘These people are your constituents as well as mine.’ I remember that then Minister Spence had no idea about the sort of suffering and indignity that certain families were facing because of the Commonwealth-state squabble over these matters. I thank the member for New England for his very timely reminder on this matter. Proposed expenditure agreed to.
